title: BRAT
transcript: 1 2 3 hi everyone brat theny green Tano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new record brat from Charlie XCX here we have the sixth official fulllength studio album from pop singer and songwriter Miss Charlie XX one of my most anticipated albums of the Year why well over the past decade in my eyes Charlie has grown into one of the most creative unique and pioneering forces in current day pop music and her Evolution has been interesting to watch to say the least I&#39;m not a fan of her early work truth be told but today it serves as an interesting reference point uh for what she&#39;s doing on this record the True Romance and sucker eras of her career uh did bring some of her biggest hits and features to date that is true but sonically much of the music she was dropping around this time wasn&#39;t very daring or even deep at best you could say it was catchy and of the time around the mid-2010s though is when Charlie&#39;s music really began to push boundaries crossing over creatively with writers and producers from the upand cominging PC music label I&#39;m talking people like Danielle harl and easy fun AG cook and the late Sophie who at the time were gaining quite the reputation for revitalizing a lot of Y2K era pop Aesthetics but with a hyper futuristic jittery sound and our first taste of this new Direction came in the form of Charlie X X X&#39;s vom vroom EP in 2016 which some critics just did not know what to make of at the time and while it was my EP of the year that year I could still see how this would have turned a lot of people off if they came into Charlie&#39;s music having certain expectations given that she was a pop artist because vroom vroom in tone is at points kind of dark and visceral and groovy in a weird way campy too with some tracks varying so wildly from part to part that uh you could almost take what she was doing here as like a joke or a novelty however the tracks on this EP are deadly serious and were also a new bold step for pop music as well as an aha moment for both Charlie and PC music creatively because at this point I think Charlie became the perfect conduit for what they were trying to channel this detailed and retrofuturistic reconstruction of 2000&#39;s pop music that lur the lines between satirical but also reverent meanwhile Charlie&#39;s creative chemistry with ag and Sophie allowed her I think to experiment more and mature as a songwriter allowing her the freedom to drop zany bangers as well as Sleek powerful anthems songs with strange structures or very unlikely features a lot of these ideas and Concepts were more or less Road tested on the mixtape she dropped back in 2017 and then in my eyes it was all fully realized on her excellent 2019 Charlie record now over the years as Charlie has developed this new sound her writing has offered more depth has become more personal and intimate especially on her pandemic album how I&#39;m feeling now but I think Charlie&#39;s writing has grown more conceptual too with her presentation as this Posh English party girl on many of her songs has more or less become like this exaggerated character she plays into however in a way Charlie&#39;s instantly recognizable sound and unique place in the pop landscape uh became both a blessing and a curse at the dawn of the 2020s because her style had gone from challenging to uh kind of definable with this newly minted hyperpop term that was uh being thrown onto everybody who sounded even vaguely like her or 100 gex and she quickly went on to strip away many of the hyper characteristics of her music on her next album crack working with a totally new team of producers and while I can&#39;t deny the record does feature some respectable hits I have to ask at what cost because crash did very measurably have quite a bit less character than anything Charlie had dropped in recent years at the time which brings us to today Charlie&#39;s latest album cycle here brat where I think she&#39;s genuinely reconnecting with the trajectory that has brought her to this point and made her a special artist to begin with even easy fun and AG cook are back in the mix on the production side on a whole lot of tracks uh numerous others too there are even references to AG cook uh on some of the lyrics to This Record as quite a bit of meta commentary is going on as well you can really tell that Charlie is fully embracing the impact she&#39;s had on pop music in recent years and uh really using it as uh more of a strength than uh weakness that she can be sort of pigeonholed into and I think that&#39;s something she can do confidently because uh her and AG cook aren&#39;t just merely trying to you know revive uh some kind of hyperpop trend on this LP I mean for sure Charlie&#39;s goal and focus is to give us this autotuned bold and hard hitting homage to 2000&#39;s era pop music but this time around we have a refreshing focus on dance pop on EDM from that era on electropop from that era Club bangers generally with a pretty aggressive Edge making this LP very worthy of the title brat because this record is meant to be danced to and at points cried to as I think Charlie&#39;s writing is more mature and thoughtful than it&#39;s ever been for one her party girl Persona takes a bit of a dark turn or at least gets deflated a bit as she reveals that it&#39;s kind of a mask and uh that she doesn&#39;t always feel uh like she&#39;s a worthy of being there at the party or you know that her and the party are a bit at odds meanwhile I think about it all all the time sees Charlie uh musing about whether or not she can continue her career in the way she currently is while also becoming a mother which he very clearly has interest in at some point skipping ahead here it&#39;s also kind of crazy how narratively this contrasts so hard with her going back full into party mode on the closing track 365 of course there are notes of nostalgia on this album too that uh is very much in line with tracks like 1999 most notably on rewind but this song specifically is more about Charlie missing older aspects of her life before the fame between sticky choruses on this track she delivers her verses in this way that kind of comes off like a conflicted internal monologue or like she&#39;s musically journaling there are lots of tracks on this thing too that deal in love but these songs narratively feel vastly different from previous singles like good ones for example tracks where historically Charlie can be seen running away from love or being a bit self-effacing and talking about how she&#39;s [ __ ] it all up instead on songs such as the really infectious talk talk to me as as well as the very cinematic everything is romantic yeah Charlie can be seen accepting love and uh doing quite a few shout outs to her fiance George but yes between this and numerous nods to wanting to have maybe a more normal life at some point Charlie really presents some interesting internal conflicts throughout this album which we also hear as well on tracks where she is singing about things like friendship and sharing the Limelight with other women I mean historically Charlie is a very proom especially when it comes to uh supporting other artists with her music through features through attention she can throw their way with her creativity I mean even look at the lyrics in the music video to one of the big singles from this record 360 that is the Charlie that most fans know and love by that same token there are numerous songs on this record where uh she is being very unfiltered in just admitting how just insecure and plagued with fear she is sometimes their sympathy is a knife where uh she talks about just being so self-conscious around this other woman that she wishes for a gun to shoot herself with which is context that some fans might even miss if they&#39;re mostly wrapped up in the Roaring bass and uh fantastic string hits going on on the dance beat there&#39;s also girl so confusing where Charlie things about the difficulties of letting people in and navigating the music industry among other people who uh she may have a difficult time connecting with knowing how to trust the song seems to be very specifically about a single person who uh maybe she&#39;s been likened to by fans but she doesn&#39;t fully see it however there&#39;s still a desire there on some level to make the friendship or the connection work then the song Von Dutch sees Charlie getting pretty aggressive and combative lyrically specifically in regards to someone who doesn&#39;t seem to like her maybe even is talking behind her back and her response to that is essentially this big anthemic [ __ ] you here where she&#39;s delivering some biting lyrics about how this person may actually be nothing if it weren&#39;t for some little dance they&#39;re doing so yeah there are these intense emotional Peaks all over the album but the biggest bombshell of all of them has to be the song so I which is very obviously a tribute to the late great producer and songwriter Sophie who actually collaborated with Charlie quite a few times so consistently in fact from an outside perspective I don&#39;t think any fan of either Charlie or Sophie would have presumed anything of them in their connection uh other than something along the lines of hey they&#39;re collaborators they have big respect for each other they love each other they&#39;re probably friends Charlie Sophie Sophie Charlie name a more iconic Duo but what Charlie says on this track here actually tells a very different story and is quite revealing in a way that is actually pretty admirable because the angle of the song is yes very sad obviously but it doesn&#39;t necessarily paint Charlie in the best light and again it&#39;s painfully sad and uh has made me reflect on the tone that uh tributes in art or whatever other medium often take they usually end up being less about the tributed person and more about the tributor love and adoration look how great I think this person is who we all think is great and Charlie&#39;s song Here does contain quite a bit of praise for Sophie that&#39;s true don&#39;t get me wrong but a lot of the track is actually an admittance on Charlie&#39;s part with her pretty much saying uh I I was a shitty friend I kind of pushed this person away I wish I didn&#39;t and now I am plagued with an insurmountable amount of regret which uh does make it a really tough listen even if I I think uh instrumentally and melodically it is one of the strongest showings here narratively and emotionally there are quite a few cuts that I think are a bit lighter in tone but they still contribute a great amount of quality to the record and are just generally fun and entertaining to listen to there&#39;s Club Classics which I thought was an incredible single to the album uh also B2B which is just some very straightforward cut and dry throwback quality dance pop with a pretty clear hot and cold back and forth Love on the Rocks type narrative there&#39;s also Apple which is some very groovy throwback synth pop 2 all about a situation and a dynamic that Charlie Likens to a rotten apple it&#39;s a situation she describes having to escape from by car by plane there&#39;s Mean Girls which is a character portrait about exactly that with a soaring and anthemic chorus plus a killer piano break that the entire track builds off of from there and then at the very end there&#39;s 365 which is the this uh version of the song 360 that kicks the record off this mirrored remix as repre big finish with some acid base mixed in there for good measure so I love the way the record finishes love the way it kicks off and the flow from moment to moment generally is great it&#39;s to the point where certain tracks in the leadup to the record that I thought were just kind of okay sound better being reinforced by The Vibes and Aesthetics of the surrounding songs on the album because as I&#39;ve heard the entire thing now many times over I don&#39;t think there&#39;s a skip on it the production generally goes hard as hell it is vibrant it is colorful it is very visceral at times aggressive but I could see some people kind of scratching their heads at the fact that it doesn&#39;t come across quite as futuristic as uh some of those hyperpop Classics in recent years but more importantly what I think the production does on this album is that it serves the songs it&#39;s sweet when it needs to be it&#39;s Dynamic when it needs to be it&#39;s lowkey or explosive when it needs to be and there&#39;s still a very clear and consistent aesthetic focus on the entire album that centers around a certain era of pop and dance music so I&#39;m not necessarily disappointed with this record not being as ahead of the curve as a project like Charlie for example especially considering that Charlie XCX copycats these days are abound the impact that people like her and Ag and Sophie have had on the modern era of pop music uh is not going any anywhere anytime soon and it&#39;s with that I say I loved brat killer album and I think that this record proves that Charlie truly is a generational pop artist which is why I&#39;m feeling a strong nine to a 10 on this LP transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should I review next hit the like if you like Please Subscribe please don&#39;t cry hit the Bell as well over here next to my head is another video you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel Anthony fantana Charlie XCX forever

title: Nina Simone Sings the Blues

ali no meio é também nessa época Quando ela começa a se apresentar que o outro nome artístico de Nina Simone Nina é porque ela tinha namorado na época que chamava ela de Ninha né ou criança ou pequena e tudo e o Simone vem em homenagem à atriz francesa Simone e sim o reto na qual ela gostava demais em 1959 ela Finalmente vai lançar o primeiro disco o neuroblue um disco que vendeu muito em cima bem então o cara falar você é muito encrenca acabou deixando ela ela realmente canta e mostra o conforte ela era como mulher bom se de considerações finais sem sombra de dúvida o Nina Simone sings the pick up the book Bob Dylan Chronicles Volume one I don&#39;t know where the next two chronicles are been waiting ten years but if you are a Bob Dylan fan or if you&#39;re even just slightly interested in this era of music he tells some you know very interesting war stories about himself other artists that he played alongside in this area and just you know this is this early part of his life now at the time this new wave of folk music you could call it wasn&#39;t just about celebrating new folk music singers it was also about sort of maintaining an American folk tradition Dylan in his years and most likely even today was obsessed with American folk singer Woody Guthrie he had this incredible reverence for him as did a lot of fans of Dylan&#39;s early work so for Dylan to go for making these socially aware politically charged acoustic ballads on a record like the times they are a-changin to going with rock instrumentation on highway 61 revisited it&#39;s not hard to see that some fans found in his discography but I think the most memorable attribute Zappa had to offer in his music was definitely his personality when I think of Frank Zappa&#39;s personality and how it fits into his music it&#39;s almost as if a musician from the 2000s had got transported back to the 1960s and 7s because of the sheer level of self-awareness that Zappa put into his music he was a guy that just loved to make fun of everything including what he did for a living He laced his humor and his worldview in his music at just about every opportunity that he could Zappa&#39;s music poked fun at hippies in the 60s on the seminal album were only in it for the money and less than 10 years later on zoo allures he was making fun of the Disco set and his other albums are also loaded with jokes about Teen Angst and love and sex and rock and roll as well as Fame and societal norms however hot rats is where a lot of the joking gets kind of cast aside in order to create a a set of mostly instrumental and exceptional Jazz Rock and jazz fusion songs which may be the most widely admired and known in the genre Zappo was not the only guy playing with these ideas at the time though he had plenty of contemporaries fusing Jazz with rock Funk and avangard composition like Miles Davis Santana Herby Hancock let&#39;s not forget the soft machine as well as one of my all-time favorites the Maha Vishnu Orchestra but Zappa&#39;s Jazz Rock tracks have a much different attitude than the songs that those artists were were putting together I know I said on this record earlier the joking kind of gets put aside but the sound the style the the feelings that get conveyed on this album are so much brighter and more fun and kookier in comparison to those artists which is not usually something Rock and especially Jazz fans smile upon since Jazz and rock are really deep and really serious genres of music but Zappa&#39;s compositional chops and his his playing on this record are so great it&#39;s hard not to admire what&#39;s going on here on at least some level if you don&#39;t come away from hot rats loving the entire album I think at least the first track is is worth loving or maybe liking this song Peaches in regalia starts with a rush of piano chords and what kind of sounds like speedily tremolo picked guitar leads I&#39;m not completely sure how that sound is created to be quite honest I know in the past Zappa has experimented with recording guitar solos to tape and then altering the speed of the tape in order to get an interesting effect I&#39;m not sure if that&#39;s what&#39;s going on here but whatever it is it&#39;s a really interesting sound and gives peaches a flavor that right after this introductory moment brass and Woodwinds kind of fly in and it&#39;s not like there&#39;s any instrument in this spot that hasn&#39;t been on another record clarinet saxophone that sort of thing but the way they&#39;re kind of pancaked onto one another it creates an interesting sound an interesting tone it&#39;s almost as if one instrument is creating this sound and it just ends up being so memorable because of that because of how strange and odd the instruments feel on here and of course Zappa&#39;s unique approach to writing Melodies only helps that after this some flute and keyboard and guitar kind of alternate for the soloing Spotlight on this track and then just before the 2-minute mark there&#39;s just this Jubilee of of bright bright horns that are just so triumphant they come off as being equal parts beautiful and quirky with a really close listen it becomes kind of apparent that this song is really really composed very planned out but it&#39;s great because Zappa and the musicians he brought on to this record jam it out so fluidly it&#39;s almost as if it&#39;s just stream of Consciousness this song is definitely a noticeable peak in the Z Zappa discography in this album it&#39;s really Zappa&#39;s compositional side at its sharpest after the opener things get dirtier looser more kind of jammed out if you&#39;re expecting you know one kind of meticulously composed Jazz Rock Opus after another you&#39;re just not going to get that the rest of the tracks on here have spots that are clearly planned out too just like peaches especially the song son of Mr Green jeans which is almost the the cousin to peaches but most of the remaining songs on here are much longer because they&#39;re they&#39;re stretched out with solos and improvs and that&#39;s great for jazz fans and people who love jazz fusion and guitar heroism but maybe not for people who love their songs short sweet simple to the point still I like all the songs following the opener on this thing and the grittiest of all of them comes right after the opener Willie The Pimp which features the gravel voice was Captain beefart a predecessor to Tom weights and he is not shy on this track at all sort of lyrically painting this image of a pimp and shouting and shrieking all over this track like he&#39;s really causing a ruckus and just the the groove and the solos just the jam of this track just feels so low down and and dirty this track is about as filthy as a wh house mattress I would say and there&#39;s this really sleazy fiddle playing all over this song which really brings that attitude home things head back in the direction of refinement on the song the son of Mr Green jeans which like I said is heavily layered and orchestrated just like peaches and regalia but on this song things really get stretched out with a lot of strong soloing and Zappa&#39;s playing is just so great on this track I can&#39;t help but eat up every note he was just such a great player the guitar was almost an extension of him you can really kind of dive into what he&#39;s playing and think about it and see that it&#39;s thoughtful but it&#39;s so fast and fluid it&#39;s almost as if it had no planning or forethought whatsoever following that song is little umbrellas which because of its lack of just blaring guitar solos is almost just a legit jazz song Simply Jazz not Jazz Rock almost a jazz song because this track is mostly made of composed moments my one real annoyance with this album is that I feel like little umbrellas could have been so much longer if it had been jammed out this song really isn&#39;t as stretched out as it could be and I think it&#39;s worth stretching out because the feeling of this track is so much different than the other songs it&#39;s more chilled out it kind of lurches forward in this really kind of sad and mysterious way I&#39;d say it&#39;s a lovable monstrosity but the lack of strong soloing on that song is made up for on the next track here that song is gumbo variations where Ian Underwood whips out his most fiery performance yet on this album his sax screams for mercy on this song this thing is a 17 minute long combo of jazz funk and rock all the composing and all the planning sort of gets thrown to the curb as saxophone violin and guitar just play so hard that even I get sweaty the closer it must be a camel kind of sends things off on a really weird note saxophones and drums kind of hit these syncopated angular Jagged Melodies it&#39;s twice the monstrosity of little umbrellas and has a lot more beef to it as well I would just like to say I love the hell out of this album and hot rats is just a standout moment in not just the Zappa discography but in jazz fusion and Jazz Rock in general I wouldn&#39;t say other albums in this style are inferior definitely not but this is one of the only albums that I know that combines Jazz and rock with these really colorfully eccentric compositions so if you really value a strong personality unique Melody writing Jazz this may become a classic for you just as it is for me this thing is definitely one of my my favorites and probably will be for the foreseeable future and now cuch chesta hey everybody uh C chesta here uh title: What's Going On
transcript: this video is sponsored by skillshare the first thousand people to click the link in the description will get a free trial of skillshare premium marvin gaye was one of the best in the world at what he did and what he did was sing songs about love throughout the 1960s gay rose to fame as one of motown records biggest stars by 1969 he had cracked the usrnb top 10 charts 25 times and even topped the pop charts with i heard it through the grapevine his delicate voice was perfect for singing about romance and heartbreak and he became one of the most important cogs in the musical machine that was motown records but while gay&#39;s career was taking off his life and the world around him were falling apart for marvin gaye fame brought with it a deep depression and a serious addiction to cocaine on top of this gay&#39;s career took a shocking turn in 1967 when his singing partner tammy terrell collapsed on stage from a brain tumor she would die three years later and as gay was dealing with this personal trauma his country was going through trauma as well the vietnam war loomed over a generation of youth and black america&#39;s civil rights movement was being met with violent resistance at every turn in 1965 the movement lost one of its greatest leaders in malcolm x and then three years later martin luther king jr was assassinated as well a year after that the fbi broke into activist fred hampton&#39;s house at four in the morning and murdered him in his sleep this hatred and violence had an effect on marvin gaye what was a singer supposed to do in the face of such pain and injustice how could you sing love songs when the government was violently repressing its own people as early as 1965 gay was starting to question his role as a musician and public figure he told his biographer that these thoughts came as a result of seeing la&#39;s watts riots my stomach got real tight and my heart started beating like crazy i wanted to throw the radio down and burn all the [ __ ] songs i&#39;d been singing and get out there and kick ass with the rest of the brothers i wonder to myself with the world exploding around me how am i supposed to keep singing love songs but barry gordy who ran motown records with an iron fist had a strict policy against artists taking political stances and so it wasn&#39;t until 1971 that marvin gaye was finally able to speak out against the injustices that he saw in the world but when gay finally did speak out it changed music forever on may 21 1971 50 years ago today marvin gaye released a pure protest album that captured the sentiment of the day and an album with lessons we can still learn from 50 years onwards that album was called what&#39;s going on the genesis for what&#39;s going on as an album came from its titular lead single that song was originally written by obi benson of the four tops he wrote it after witnessing police dressed in riot gear who were obscuring badges and assaulting students in berkeley california benson told ben edmonds about his reaction to this scene i saw this and started wondering what the [ __ ] was going on what is happening here one question led to another why are they sending kids so far from their families overseas why are they attacking their own children in the streets here benson took that question and turned it into a song but the four tops refused to record it thanks to motown&#39;s policy on politics but benson knew he had something so when his band members turned down his song he brought it to marvin gaye the lyrics were perfect for an artist who was looking to say something about the world [Music] they were filled with a pacifist tilt talking about the vietnam war but hinted at everything else going on as well don&#39;t punish me with brutality [Music] and even though gordy insisted that motown should be apolitical gay went about and recorded the song anyways that recording session was filled with spontaneous creativity the eli fontaine sac solo that opened the song was just fontaine improvising and loosening up before recording it was serendipity that gave the song its iconic vocals too with several vocal takes layered over one another this came about because gay wanted to listen to two different vocal takes to hear which was better engineer ken sands put one on each side of the stereo mix so they could be compared in real time but gay loved the sound of them together and so he decided to keep it adding multiple vocal layers throughout the choruses of the song the energy and freedom comes through in the sessions with chatter between gay&#39;s friends making it into the mix as well altogether the song is vibrant and lush you can hear gay coming to life as he&#39;s finally able to get his catharsis speaking out against the evils in the world but when gay brought the recording to gordy he was shot down in frankie gay&#39;s memoir he recalls a phone call with his brother where marvin vented about barry gordy barry hates my music he doesn&#39;t want to record it because he doesn&#39;t think it will sell he may be right about that but i don&#39;t care i just want to be heard and that&#39;s all that matters but even as gordy was shutting down the song other powers at the label worked in secret to get it released and in january 1971 to the surprise of both gay and barry gordy what&#39;s going on hit record stores it immediately proved gordy wrong not only did what&#39;s going on sell it became the fastest selling single motown had ever seen moving more than 70 000 copies in its first week and that&#39;s because what&#39;s going on struck a vein with people all across america who were asking themselves that exact same question with the success of the single the tables turned barry gordy came to marvin gaye and asked him for an album to follow it up with the ball entirely in his court gay bargained for complete creative control barry&#39;s only stipulation was that the album needed to be completed by the end of march so with carte blanche marvin gaye went about making the protest album that he had dreamed of making the recording sessions for what&#39;s going on were unorthodox gay and his team would work 12-hour days bring friends into the studio and go through prodigious amounts of scotch and gay looked beyond motown&#39;s typical roster of musicians and songwriters mercy me featured a sack solo from the early rock saxophonist wild bill moore and motown&#39;s elevator operator james nix helped contribute lyrics to three songs on the album it was a far cry from the assembly line process that had defined motown up until that point the result is music that&#39;s loose and groovy with a warm sound that would define r b in the early 70s lyrically the album is a broad protest album that talks about all of the issues that gay saw in his day when he first pitched the album to gordy marvin gaye described it as protesting vietnam police brutality social conditions a lot of stuff and song by song gay addresses all of these the second track on the album is what&#39;s happening brother written from the perspective of a vietnam veteran who comes home to find his country in tatters the character finds that the country he left has changed and that he no longer has a place in it he can&#39;t get a job and the culture has moved at such a pace that he can&#39;t keep up these experiences were inspired by the true story of marvin gaye&#39;s brother frankie who fought in vietnam for three years but it wasn&#39;t just frankie gay&#39;s experience countless young men throughout the 1960s were drafted into an imperialistic war went through hellish trauma and returned to a country that fundamentally did not care for them especially if they were black while the protests against the vietnam war were very much rooted in their time much of the rest of the album is just as relevant today we live in an age of police brutality ecological disaster and systemic apathy where millions are left behind by the governments meant to protect and aid them the third song on what&#39;s going on is flying high in the friendly sky a raw portrait of gay&#39;s own struggles with addiction [Music] 50 years later addiction remains an epidemic in much of north america today throughout the 2010s the prescription opioid crisis ravaged communities that were already impoverished by the 2008 financial crisis it&#39;s these kinds of systemic issues that can make us feel despondent about the world a feeling that gay captures in the next song save the children i just want to ask a question who really cares save a world in despair what&#39;s going on even features a song of environmental protest mercy mercy me the ecology in this song in particular gay was ahead of his time predicting the environmental concerns that loom over generations of youth today but the most relevant song of all might be the last song of the album inner city blues make me want to holler [Music] inner city blues is about the economic disenfranchisement of the lower classes people forced to work long hours for low pay and denied access to basic human rights like housing and healthcare the apollo program of the 1960s and the moon landing were great triumphs for humanity but they rang hollow to a generation of black americans struggling to put food on the table 50 years later tech billionaires are shooting for mars while people starve in the streets and cities burn from climate change choosing to dream of sci-fi futures in space rather than address the real tangible problems here on earth gay discusses one of the biggest of those problems in the fourth verse [Music] the over-policing of poor communities has a long history in the united states it was one of the defining struggles that marvin gaye faced and has only increased with the growth of america&#39;s prison industrial complex 50 years onwards these words probably resonate more than any others on the album as we sit in the midst of a historic movement against police brutality when faced with all the same problems marvin gaye looked back to his early career and looked to the force that had driven him to stardom love but gay didn&#39;t mean a simple romantic love for him love meant a love of his god a love of the planet he lived on and most of all a true grand love for all of humankind in right on gay sings about the power that love can have to bring people [Music] together [Music] but what does love for your fellow man really mean in the modern world i don&#39;t think it simply means being nice to people respecting people i think that love for your fellow man means something greater it means understanding that there are certain rights that everybody is entitled to it means knowing that people deserve clean water healthy food in their bellies roofs above their head and fair pay for fair work and it means being willing to push for these changes on a systemic level even if that means your life might personally change in marvin gaye&#39;s case it meant pushing against a label that told him not to get political love meant using his platform to raise awareness and to fight for causes he believed in what&#39;s going on was a massive risk for marvin gaye but it paid dividends not only did the album sell but it also changed perspectives of what soul music could be suddenly people started to look to motown for the kind of culture shifting records that rock and roll had produced over the last decade in the wake of marvin gaye more motown and soul artists like stevie wonder began to use their platform to speak out creating ambitious works of auteurship in the example that gay set and even today the influence of the album can still be felt marvin gaye&#39;s ethos lives on through the current generation of conscious hip-hop artists like kendrick lamar vince staples and killer mike and in 2020 when rolling stone updated their list of the 500 greatest albums of all time they placed what&#39;s going on at the very top what&#39;s going on didn&#39;t solve the issues of its day but it helped bring awareness to them and helped set a new standard for how musicians can fight them and today 50 years onwards i think that what&#39;s going on merits re-listening and reflection the dreams of marvin gaye may feel far off but with a new generation of youth standing up and fighting for what they believe in perhaps we will finally be able to find the love that marvin gaye was looking for half a century ago with what&#39;s going on marvin gaye proved the title: Marquee Moon
transcript: [Music] released in February of 1977 televisions debut long-player Markie moon is an artful collection of twin guitar explorations symbolist poetics and hard-boil narratives the LP remains one of the high-water marks of New York City&#39;s mid seventies punk explosion which included Patti Smith blondie The Ramones and Talking Heads all of whom played regularly at the tiny Bowery club known as CBGB [Music] television originally consisting of guitarists Tom Verlaine and Richard Lloyd fuss drummer Billy Vika and bassist Richard hell got there first in early 1974 the band convinced cv g&#39;v owner Hilly Kristal to let them take over the club&#39;s typically dead Sunday night slot and soon earned a fiercely devoted audience but the band lagged behind its Punk peers and actually releasing a full-length LP Patti Smith sources hit stores in 1975 and the self-titled debut zuv both blondie and the Ramones soon followed in 76 with a volatile line-up and a mercurial frontman in for Lane it seemed possible the television might never get around to painting its masterpiece [Music] the road to marquis moon was a rocky one televisions first foray into a pro studio situation came in late 1974 the bam cutter demo with Island Records A&amp;R man Richard Williams an art rock provocateur Brian Eno fresh out of Roxy music a record geeks dream come true perhaps but for lane and Lloyd were unimpressed with the results unable to jibe with Eno&#39;s unorthodox methods at one point he suggested suspending the band&#39;s amplifiers from the studio&#39;s ceiling the tapes remain unreleased though heavily bootleg to this day [Music] television forged ahead over the next two years replacing Richard hell with Fred Smith and honing their sound to a razor-sharp point during regular residences at CBGB to help bring televisions vision to wax at long last the band enlisted decidedly unpunctual and the Rolling Stones but the pairing was an inspired one as John&#39;s delivered a tough relatively unadorned sound for marquee moon Lloyd&#39;s painstakingly double track guitar lines gained a crystalline flavor while Verlaine&#39;s more spontaneous excursions provided a perfect counterpoint [Music] [Applause] [Music] Encino evil the album&#39;s revved up opener relaying promises to pull down the future over lloyd&#39;s churning riff [Music] venus is a surrealistic nocturnal journey punctuated by an elegantly intertwining six-string refrain from the two guitarists [Music] like little wager friction meanwhile is television at their garage rockiest with roll aim spewing free jazz inspired fireworks over a rock steady backing from Boyd thicket and Smith [Music] looming at Marquee moons direct center is the album&#39;s title track clocking in at just under 10 minutes on the original vinyl release and featuring a lengthy four lane guitar solo Markie moon is miles away from the Ramones minimalist rock antics or Blondie&#39;s ironic pop moves for precedence look to the expansive West Coast psychedelia of Quicksilver Messenger service or even the Grateful Dead even if the mid seventies crowd at CBGB would likely shudder touch comparisons [Music] upon its release the enemy is Nick Kent called Marquis moon a 24-karat inspired work of pure genius a record finally in tune and sublimely arranged with a whole new slant on dynamics other records might wither in the face of such a rave but 40 years later Markie moon remains a singular achievement that transcends the punk label and still sounds as fresh today as it did in 1977 [Music] you

title: Bitches Brew
transcript: my sons my daughters how are you I hope you&#39;re well I hope you&#39;re well Anthony fantano here internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for yet another review of an older album for Classics week Miles Davis [ __ ] Brew Miles Davis trumpeteer band leader composer and one of the most versatile musicians in jazz really since Miles Davis started putting out solo albums it seemed that no matter what new idea or musical concept was coming up in jazz he was there to either spearhead it or just wholeheartedly embrace it with a topnotch album that rang true of Bop of cool also his modal Masterpiece kind of blue and later in the late &#39; 60s and early&#39; 70s when avanguard Jazz and fusions of jazz and rock music seemed to be the next new hot thing he was there innovating and while this LP is maybe not my favorite of his Fusion pieces and and definitely not the easiest to listen to there are moments where it does get pretty damn impenetrable I in a way sort of prefer in a silent way for for a shorter easier listen the grooves are a bit clearer the ambient esque interludes on this album are gorgeous and it all seems to be a little bit more composed later after [ __ ] Brew miles would fly in the face of funk and an afro beat with albums like on the corner and the extremely fiery and kind of psychedelic aarta but [ __ ] bruise undying popularity does kind of make it miles definitive Fusion piece and it&#39;s really know wonder why I definitely think the Strong Rock influence on this LP does make it sort of an easy transition for rock music fans this album also for its time had a very ear-catching name as well as an illustrious album cover plus the extremely lengthy list of guest musicians and a very long runtime does make this album pretty much mil&#39;s most ambitious foray into this style of music every track on this LP is a panoramic display of these very loose fluid jams that are very instrument and improv heavy this album is actually pretty post- production intensive for a jazz LP there are a lot of insong edits as well as Echoes reverbs tape delays the sounds on this LP are so clear and sharp and Vivid throw this on some headphones and it&#39;s actually like sitting there in the middle of the studio session there are instruments all over the place there are at least two drummers on every single track typically one mix all the way in the Left Channel and another mixed all the way in the right and the same goes for electric piano players too the track X Pharaoh&#39;s dance in Spanish key feature three electric piano players each now as far as some of my favorite and most notable players on this LP for one there is John mlin guitar player and Billy [ __ ] both who made fantastic music in the infamous Maha Vishnu Orchestra Jack D Janette also brings drums chick Korea plays some fantastic electric piano all over this thing Wayne shorter soprano saxs Joe zenel electric piano and each of them contribute some writing to this LP as well and there are many many other players outside of these guys on this LP2 just a lot of great jazz fusion Giants on this album that either had their own solo albums or projects out there a lot of them on the very jazz fusion friendly label ECM records and another thing that kind of steps this album outside of the traditional Jazz realm for the most part it is electric and just rock instrumentation on this thing the only obvious exceptions being Miles Davis and Wayne shorter but of course Benny Alpin is on a ton of tracks here playing his very prevalent bass clarinet it does feel kind of weird having a woodwind in the midst of all of these guitars and and drum sets on this LP but it actually adds a pretty interesting texture on a lot of these songs I mean with the production the players the instrumentation and the song lengths [ __ ] Brew can pretty much be summed up in one single word and that is excess and I wouldn&#39;t even say it&#39;s like well-groomed excess on a lot of songs here miles is completely happy to sort of lay a Tempo or a groove or a mood or a key out there and just kind of let the jam progress naturally beyond that quietly urging certain band members to improvise at certain times there is definitely not a tight snazzy swinging feel to this LP which usually gets associated with the word Jazz it just goes to show how much of a jazz purist Miles Davis was not if anything he was in fact just an improvisation purist and while [ __ ] Brew was not exactly pushing the Avant guard jazz or The Improv Envelope as hard as some other LPS that came out around this time did or even some LPS that preceded this album [ __ ] Brew is certainly one of the best full lengths when it comes to improv of this shade something that is performed with a large band very lengthy and rock influenced there are parts of these tracks that do feel very clearly composed whether they be introductions or themes or just sort of syncopated riffs something like that that brings the song from one area to another for example the very kind of refined and and slow buildup of instrumentation on this album&#39;s title track as well as miles bright and echoed shots of trumpet once this passes some base guitar and bass clarinet comes through starts playing some lines and the song goes into its next phase a very dark Moody and funky Groove but it&#39;s not like a good time funky Groove I mean it&#39;s just got this very sour quality to it it has this heavy sense of uncertainty everybody&#39;s trying to make note of what everyone else is doing but also be heard and and add something worthwhile it&#39;s this tension that kind of makes the songs on this LP sound a certain way this song and many others on here just bring the just awesome electricity of improvisational chance it&#39;s like what&#39;s going to happen next wow they are really riding this groove so hard it&#39;s getting more tense it&#39;s getting less tense you don&#39;t really get these very clear posts moving any of these tracks from point A to point B to point C when the songs on here shift it&#39;s it&#39;s very kind of subtle or gradual shift the music doesn&#39;t just kind of break into a catchy melody or anything like that it doesn&#39;t bring the tension into a sweet spot so that you can kind of have a break and not think of what&#39;s going on and if the NeverEnding sense of tension for 20 sometimes almost 30 minutes makes you uncomfortable and totally turns you off to the idea of listening to a record then that&#39;s fine maybe the selfie isn&#39;t for you but regardless of how planned out this album is or isn&#39;t I will say that you&#39;re basically hearing on this album track for track some fantastic performances from some of the best players in this style around this time now as far as other notable moments outside of the jams easily the introduction to to the song Pharaoh&#39;s dance that Baseline right at the beginning is unmistakable and the droplets of electric piano slowly falling onto that track are just gorgeous it&#39;s such again a very Vivid cinematic song If the first two tracks the longest two tracks on this LP are maybe a little too dismal a little too long- winded for you or uneventful then definitely try out the song Spanish key really one of the more hard grooving tracks on this album and on this track you really do feel the those double drum sets as the band is hitting some really fast tempos as they boil over with energy plus there&#39;s a spot in the song where John mlin and and chick Korea are dueling in each Channel guitar and electric piano it&#39;s fantastic hearing them Just Bounce leads and Melodies off of one another after that Wayne shorter has a huge solo piece in the middle of this song and his playing is fantastic especially when he hits those high notes and lets them ring out and the way he moves and sh shifts in intensity as the band gets louder or gets softer Underneath Him is just really impressive around 8:45 on the song This riff sort of Pops in that changes the song into another gear or just sort of a a revamped Groove that&#39;s not the only time this occurs in that track but it&#39;s really one of the most clear sort of shifts from One Moment In a song to another on this entire LP like I said there are changes and there are posts on this album it&#39;s just that they&#39;re usually pretty subtle and sort of slow arriving really the meat and potatoes and what makes this album so attractive are the jams John mlin kills it on the track that he&#39;s attached to Miles Davis runs the voodoo down is another hard groving song if you&#39;ve loved Spanish key and what was once The Closer on here Sanctuary before a lot of modern reissues of this LP added another song toward the end of this album which is also awesome but still back to Sanctuary I love the skittering drums on that track and the way the slow moving and echoed horns kind of interact with the drum sets on the track it&#39;s just so so strange there&#39;s not much more that I could say about this LP in terms of describing the tracks I mean to go beyond where I am now I feel like would be insane I would be describing literal solo moments in the middle of the songs and the thing is if if how I&#39;ve described this album generally sounds completely like a turnoff to you then chances are you don&#39;t care what the solo sound like if you&#39;re looking to get into jazz music there are more access ible and more traditional albums that you could listen to a lot of them made by Miles Davis but if you want to listen to some really strong unique improvisational music with some potent moods some very clear Vivid instrumentation just piled in layers upon layers upon layers that you can really get lost in for hours and hours at a time then give this a try Miles Davis [ __ ] Brew if you&#39;ve given this a listen what did you think about it did you love it did you title: Remain in Light
transcript: up hey everyone Anthony fantano here internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a classic review classic classic classic review of Talking Heads remain in light 1980 album legendary new wave and postp punk outfit Talking Heads David burn Tina way mouth Chris France Terry Harrison formed in 1975 and they were one of many great bands to play at the legendary New York music club cbgbs which was formerly the stomping grounds of many greats television Richard hell the Ramones Patty Smith Sonic Youth the list is endless the place was literally a petri dish for some of the most essential alternative music ever recorded now in their early years Talking Heads sound was a bit of a crossover kind of a bridge between two worlds the band while their music was alternative and had the eccentricities and and the risk-taking qualities of punk music they were very in touch with contemporary pop and dance music as well borrowing grooves from the worlds of disco and funk and applying them to some really strange ideas eccentric vocals and lyrics from David burn really Herky and jerky bass and guitars Give a listen to the iconic single Psycho Killer if you&#39;re kind of looking for an example over time the band&#39;s music would only get more ambitious bigger instrumentation awesome ballads like the song Heaven an eyebrow raising cover of Take Me to the River incorporating elements of African music especially into the Rhythm Section of their music the band&#39;s rhythms became smoother more dancable in a way more accessible but still simultaneously David Burn&#39;s vocal performances would also become Wilder and this would all come to aead on the band&#39;s 1980 record remain in light their most popular studio album which also contained their most significant hit song Once in a Lifetime and with Brian Eno on production of Roxy Music Fame he&#39;s also had some great solo records ambient works this album would not be assembled in the same way that previous Talking Heads records were the songs on this album are essentially a series of licks and Snippets and Loops recorded from the band itself and then assembled into these longer compositions and the instrumentals are masterfully assembled as the grooves on this thing really hold water we&#39;re talking about a lot of instrumental layers on this thing considering that that many of them are samples that many of them are just chunks of sounds guitars bass vocals and background vocals horns poly rhythms and hand percussions synths and various sound effects and weird glitchy edits none of this Probably sounds all that radical in an age of LCD sound system but when you consider this album came out in 1980 in a musical landscape of Michael Jackson Olivia Newton John sticks Air Supply hardcore punk Blondie Queen Billy Joel and straightforward synth pop this thing&#39;s pretty Progressive the grooves on this thing as I said they&#39;re Flawless they&#39;re hypnotic they&#39;re fluid throughout the entire record and the album essentially Works in two halves it kicks off with a really explosive visceral start and then eventually into something way more abstract and Spacey around houses in motion the song Born Under punches starts the entire record it&#39;s a song that is as funky as it is unsettling the track features these popped pronounced baselines very jerky guitars it&#39;s clunky it&#39;s cluttered but it&#39;s got a beat to it a really good beat too uh I also like the little diddling Eerie strange guitars that sort of find themselves looping back into the track again and again and again and David Burn&#39;s lyrics Here seem like uh he&#39;s talking about government oppression and pressure to sort of lead a certain life or give into what the system wants you to do which is not a new lyrical theme for him but it seems like he&#39;s approaching it in a more abstract way with these really pronounced Pro proclamations I&#39;m a tumbler and then chilling the goes out with these very stone-faced refrains as he&#39;s singing All I want is to breathe there&#39;s also a freaky Twisted guitar solo on this thing that sounds like it was mangled in a tape machine or something I love the studio trickery that goes into this record there&#39;s so much detail in the these linear hypnotic songs and there&#39;s also a really cool refrain in the second half that I like a lot I sort of wonder if lyrically it&#39;s kind of a play on the idea uh that the beat goes on but David burn and Company are singing instead the heat goes on and the heat goes on and the heat goes on the song&#39;s cross-eyed and painless and the great curve really turn the heat up intensify the record they deliver some of the tightest speediest beats the dense layers of instrumentation on this thing are awesome the vocals the guitars the poly rhythms the bass the keys and lyrically once again David burn sort of goes neurotic much in the way that he was on Psycho Killer and many other tracks too as he obsesses over lines and shapes and facts underneath David Burn&#39;s emotional chaos each instrument is sort of just like a little tiny sliver of sound and Melody sort of just a very small embellishment that all together creates this larger tapestry I just love the layers on this record I love how the Assembly of these sounds comes together especially as the band Works in these refrains these vocal refrains that are all thrown on top of each other it&#39;s not odd to hear three different refrains being being sung over one another at different speeds and paces the great curve is an example of that and lyrically this song is I think uh going into this idea of being anxious over not completely understanding the world and this is set against imagery of a woman dancing and this woman is being controlled maybe remote controlled it seems like those themes of government control or system control are coming back that were introduced at the int track and with the song once in a lifetime we have a career defining group Grove on this thing I mean it&#39;s it&#39;s so good boom boom boom and this Baseline is just plunged into a sea of just swirling sparkling shimmering arpeggios and the band maintains the beat as they switch from this chorus that is super sweet Soulful inspiring almost Heavenly and then these very pronounced animated spoken word vocals uh the comparison has been made before that David burn sounds a lot like a preacher on this track and I have to agree it&#39;s it&#39;s almost as if he&#39;s you know telling the crowd something preaching something but but that only kind of comes through in the tone of his voice I feel like lyrically this song is a little too abstract and it&#39;s really just supposed to confuse and emotionally stir the listener and kind of reflect on the speed of life and how water for example is brought up as a theme in this track is kind of like the current pushing you onto the next stage of life and you can&#39;t really control it the album goes dark and introspective on houses in motion David Burn&#39;s vocals turn very soft very quiet spoken word and then he&#39;s switching that off title: Hounds of Love
transcript: hi everyone triumphs in a car tan oh here the Internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of a classic album because classic sweet Kate Bush is an English singer-songwriter and producer who has been dropping albums since the late 70s and has seen incredible success across the length of her career from her debut single weathering Heights which was a number-one single in the UK and dropped when Kate was still a teen - her latest full-length album fifty words for snow which was very well received and came out not too long ago kate is one of those artists whose miraculously been able to attain mainstream success while also pleasing very discerning music fans and on top of all of it crafting a distinct sound that has made her one of modern music&#39;s most praised voices her music is highly influential even today thanks to her fantastic songwriting as well as her pioneering in art pop and baroque pop and some of her greatest and most timeless ideas turn up here on her 1985 album hounds of love a record loaded with lofty and dramatic ideas but surprisingly the songs still stay very direct instantaneous visceral catchy much of the material on this record is incredibly pleasing on first listen this isn&#39;t really a record you need to sit with and repeat time and time again in order to good though more lessons do reveal more beautiful details and the lyrics and the instrumentation but this album&#39;s explosive love ability is thanks in part to the first half&#39;s immense singles Big Sky the title track running up that hill as well as cloud busting but the second half of this LP titled something else entirely the ninth wave feels like a different project entirely and what begins this suite of songs is sort of like a musical dream sequence Kate even says in the lyrics she can&#39;t be left alone with her imagination nation nations because it seems like she&#39;s haunted by lingering memories and pretty disturbing nightmares in the following tracks a lot of the songs on this half of the record are kind of stirring occasionally surreal lyrically and sonically some of the experimentation here is quite jarring and in my opinion kind of a precursor to a lot of what would occur on records from Bjork and the knife years down the road K even pulls from Celtic music on the incredibly lush jig of life so not only his hounds of love a strange diverse and beautiful record but it&#39;s also a payoff that came after an initial risk from Kate Kate&#39;s previous LP the dreaming an enjoyable album but not really her most successful commercially was the first time she tried to take on production duties all on her own some of the mixing on this record was a little odd Kate&#39;s vocals were incredibly loud on some songs and instrumentally this set of songs was a little more skeletal than her previous work less extravagant than some of the music on her previous record especially considering on that album landed songs like babushka and the song violin to another Kate Bush song I&#39;m just head over heels for especially due to the progressive rock influence on that track which isn&#39;t too big of a surprise considering that David Gilmour of Pink Floyd was an early and huge supporter of Kate&#39;s music career so taking the experience from the Dreaming and now working with a series of engineers and fantastic session musicians one of which is her brother Kate really comes through with an undeniable hit commercially and artistically and she also makes sure to embrace the blossoming world of synth pop on this record - with some really bold hooks and very prominent keyboards on a lot of the cuts here there is more arranged instrumentation - in comparison with the dreaming this LP is so much more lush take into account all the multi-tracked vocals on the song big sky which makes that track just feel huge hounds of love really helped Kate gain that international audience that she still maintains today even with incredibly minimal touring and live performances because in the case of Kay Bush the music is really all you need running up that hill incredible opener for this record epic galloping rhythm that kicks this song off the kind of a rhythm that wouldn&#39;t be too unfamiliar to someone who was listening to new wave and synth pop a cave really does this rhythm one better with some really thunderous percussion on the hook and I love the way Kate&#39;s voice just juts into the instrumental as if she&#39;s attacking as she&#39;s singing and from what I can hear in this track she seems to be singing about two lovers one of whom the protagonist here really wishes to make a deal with God in order to have the other the significant other sort of understand our protagonists point of view what she is going through just to come to some kind of better understanding which seems like a very simple desire but the way Kate approaches the song lyrically with such poetic words and instrumentally she makes this wish seem so grand and so urgent so huge on the title track of the selfie Kate&#39;s voice just sticks out once again there&#39;s kind of a very sharp reverb as if she recorded her vocals in like a stone hallway or something she&#39;s like a vocal ray of light just shining brightly right in your face in the midst of very urgent string sections Airy sense and a very spacious expressive drumbeat but my favorite single on side a of this LP has to be cloud busting which is hands down one of the best baroque pop songs ever just some simple strings playing the chords of the song a very strict back drumbeat and vocal melody this track doesn&#39;t need much more to make it fantastic because the writing is just that good the vocal melody is so amazing Kate singing is incredibly dramatic but she doesn&#39;t take away from the the catchiness of the song by just overdoing and even while holding back her singing is still a very emotional experience and the lyrics of the song there&#39;s a real sense of anticipation the second half of this record as I said earlier really is its own beast it&#39;s a very abstract and what I interpret to be a kind of personal set of tracks starting with a very dreamy reflective intro and the following track under the ice feels like the initial entrance into the dreamscape later down the line the jig of life has some really boisterous strings I really determined drum be it&#39;s not a single but every bit as thrilling as many of the cuts on the first half I love the acoustic direction the instrumental takes on this track and Kate&#39;s singing on this song is just definition of conviction then there&#39;s the sonically disturbing waking which very few musicians and lusts Mort is one of them create sounds that to me are literally frightening and Kate Bush is one of those artists in this case the loud sound effects and the choppy weird vocals that enter into the track at one point and seem to be kind of a theme on this half of the record which might seem like another memory calling her to another part of this dream state or maybe even real-life trying to pull her out of this dream state entirely I&#39;m not totally sure but it&#39;s you know really a weird disturbing thing other voices and singers actually play a pretty significant role on this half of the record as if K is playing the lead orchestra inspired instrumentation that kind of segues the song from one part to another and Kate unlike some other people who also try to go down this direction can give that musical theatre like presentation while also maintaining that intimate passion that you should feel with with a singer/songwriter this track really coasts down fades out and disintegrates very slowly it kind of feels like title: Tang Clan
transcript: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here Internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for another album review classics week continues celebrating 50k 50k wu-tang clan enter the wu-tang 36 chambers wu-tang is a still active New York hip-hop outfit that was formed in the early 90s this is their debut LP dropped in 1993 and it&#39;s been followed up with numerous studio albums since but whoo tang is one of those groups whose debut LP kind of overshadows the rest of their albums people usually don&#39;t give the rest of their material the time of day even though albums like their sophomore LP wu-tang forever are pretty good but that&#39;s not a huge issue since every single one of the group&#39;s nine members has released solo material and a lot of that is as essential as 36 chambers like Ghostface Killah solo stuff which is my favorite out of all of the wu-tang clan&#39;s solo release material fish-scale ironman supreme clientele also Raekwon with only built 4 Cuban Linx parts 1 &amp; 2 ol Dirty Bastard with the return of the 36 chambers the dirty version and of course we can&#39;t forget the jizzes Liquid Swords those are some of my favorites but no matter how much I like those albums this release is the Alpha this is where it all goes back to this is where it starts and you must start now whoo tang and this album were an essential part to the evolving face of hip-hop in the 90s this album is a move past the golden age hip-hop sounds that came out in the 80s the jazz rap and socially conscious rap sounds that were being dropped by groups like De La Soul and A Tribe Called Quest in the in the very early 90s and late 80s and the West Coast sounds of gangsta rap that were being dropped at the time too by guys like Ice Cube and waa and dr. dre keep in mind this is just a really quick abridged version of this evolution there are a lot more artist sounds and albums at work here because when people talk about this era of hip-hop especially the west coast side of things groups like freestyle fellowship for example are often forgotten so in the early in mid 90s the New York hip-hop scene was reinventing itself as something much grittier tougher more aggressive and ready to battle of course there are a lot of individual New York emcees that played a role in that like nas and notorious b.i.g but wu-tang definitely stuck out and was unique in their amount of members not to say that none of these guys would have made it if they&#39;ve stayed solo their entire career but wu-tang power clearly comes from strength in numbers because with nine different people and seeing on these really hard-hitting stripped down beats this album sort of gives the atmosphere the feel of a never-ending cypher a rap battle there are a couple songs here where one MC will take the spotlight Method Man where Method Man is all over that song and of course claim in the front where GZA is pretty much featured on that track but on the majority of the tracks here is just one MC after another taking turns on these beats and because of that it sounds like they&#39;re way more hyped than they would be otherwise it&#39;s like a competition it makes this record come off with just a lot of energy and energy that is really infectious and with tracks that have gang courses like ain&#39;t nothing to [ __ ] with and these really hard hard grooves and rize&#39;s beats this album has just a ton of momentum which makes it really hard for me to just not go nuts when listening to this thing and because most of this album sounds like a rap battle there&#39;s a very specific kind of lyricism going on amidst these tracks hilarious insults cartoony violence a barrage of brags and non sequiturs and cultural references there&#39;s about as much ferocity and testosterone on this as like a hardcore punk record so there&#39;s no question that enter the wu-tang is meant to be raw rugged dirty and stoned but it&#39;s music you know it&#39;s entertainment there&#39;s no reason to take a lot of the violence and bragging on this LP that seriously because it&#39;s so outlandish and ridiculous the real goal here is just to kind of be extreme and out there which i think is definitely highlighted on a sketch that comes before the song Method Man where they&#39;re kind of going back and forth talking about torture and another clear goal here is just to be clever funny witty if you can get into the lyricism on this thing you&#39;re going to hear a lot of great wordplay and a lot of fantastic quotables and to add another level of greatness to this record I love that every single emcee on this thing comes into these tracks with a different sound and a different style I hate it when I&#39;m listening to a rap track and it&#39;s got two three four MCS on it and they all sound the same none of them have any flavor you can&#39;t really pull anybody out is being any kind of specific or bold thing not the case here everyone on this album has their own angle Ghostface Killah is the most hyped MC out of all of them he mostly works in the upper register of his voice throws out a lot of battle raps the GZA is extremely cunning and clever in the rhymes he chooses Raekwon has this nice rasp to his voice and he pulls out a lot of vivid street life imagery Method Man has this really kind of partytime attitude he&#39;s really chilled out laid-back looking for a good time at every possible direction and ol Dirty Bastard who I think isn&#39;t the most lyrical here but he&#39;s the most fun to listen to he combines rapping with this really weird kind of off kazoo like it&#39;s he&#39;s nuts or he was rather he&#39;s got this really low voice he slurs all of his words he&#39;s like a rabid dog now let&#39;s talk about the beats a little bit I guess the beats on this thing definitely helped bring wu-tang together into this aesthetic of course there was kind of a battle rap cypher thing going on amongst these tracks but there was also a certain sound to the music behind the rapping of course the name of the group is a tribute to old kung fu movies and that definitely gets brought home in a lot of the samples and clips of dialogue from these films too in the lyrics there&#39;s a lot of talk of swordplay and martial arts and it really kind of brings this album a huge sense of of camaraderie like you&#39;re coming up against a gang of lyrical ninjas in a hip-hop dojo but overall the beats here I think it&#39;s just kind of a case of of less is more because it&#39;s not like there&#39;s a whole lot to them and not to say that they&#39;re not intricate not to say that the sounds on these beats aren&#39;t interesting I&#39;m just saying it&#39;s definitely not like a lot of modern hip-hop which is just saturated with a ton of different sounds poppin melodic catchy hooks R&amp;B singers on this thing like a lot of hip-hop at the time there are ton of piano samples but RZA didn&#39;t just pick some kind of sweet or soulful piano break or something like that it seemed almost as if he was choosing the most sour weird most unused melodies notes and chords that he could get his hands on because claimed in the front 7th chamber and Method Man all have really weird piano phrases laid into the beat and there are even moments like cream where all the samples come together to create something that&#39;s really kind of chilled out atmospheric and eerie the drums on here have a really punchy analogue sound that&#39;s really kind of typical for hip-hop at that time really kind of classic style and there are some songs on here that clearly sample music from the very kung-fu movies that inspire the group&#39;s aesthetic - there&#39;s just one unique sound after another in every one of these beats and it just adds to the aggressive and unsettling atmosphere of this album they&#39;re very textured instrumentals that just leave a lot of room just make space for the lyrics for the emceeing and that&#39;s perfect to me like I said these beats are just saturated with a ton of sounds like today&#39;s hip-hop and not to dis where hip-hop has gone I mean I don&#39;t think today&#39;s hip-hop is terrible I just think it&#39;s interesting when you consider how much hip-hop has changed in the almost 20 years since this album has been released so yeah on this LP there are a lot of brags battle raps and tough personalities and beats but it&#39;s not like that&#39;s the entirety of this album there are some spots on here that are worth kind of thinking about the deeper meaning of like the song cream which stands for cash rules everything around me and even though it sounds like a really kind of greedy and stereotypical hip-hop statement that song isn&#39;t really a celebration of that it&#39;s just kind of a really gritty picture of what it&#39;s like to grow up poor and you&#39;re in a position where making very fast illegal money seems like the only way out of that and the song tears which comes around the end of this LP is about friends and family members dying after making some bad decisions like deciding to have unprotected sex with a lot of different people or refusing to hand money over to somebody who&#39;s trying to mug you at gunpoint 36 Chambers is definitely an aggressive album but it&#39;s not an aggression that should make you feel threatened it&#39;s an aggression that you get you pumped this thing is just a messy grimy and unbreakable 90s hip-hop album and there&#39;s not much more to it than that this thing is a classic it&#39;s an important part of hip hop&#39;s history but if you&#39;re not a hip hop fan I&#39;m not going to promise to you that this thing is going to change your worldview if you haven&#39;t heard this album after all 36 chambers is the archetype for a lot of the lyricism we hear in hip hop today if you haven&#39;t heard this thing before and you&#39;re just not all that school than 90&#39;s hip hop in general try this thing out and at least get a sense for where a lot of modern hip hop&#39;s ideas come from just to kind of hear them at their best for that time wu-tang 36 chambers counter chesa no one&#39;s who you know is matching up the couch asta when i spit this floor it&#39;s more electrical than Tesla send your support please free Cal so I could do some shows and tour your locale you could quote me here my rhymes are brand and clever I&#39;m saying it now but you&#39;ll be saying it forever you
