through it and uh really pay attention to each detail plus the ascending horn transitions that hit in between these passages following that the loose and dramatic instrumental passages over which grief describes this a surreal and very strange violent boxing match whole thing sounds like it was made up in a fever dream and from section to section of the story it really moves like a roller coaster the song eat men eat instrumentally is almost as brutal with unsettling blends of prague rock and jazz but this one goes in a slightly more acoustic direction the contrast between the relaxed verses and vicious choruses is devastating there are a few other changes to note too like the vocals now being taken on by uh cameron picton who doesn&#39;t come across vocally as bold or as in command of whatever pitch he&#39;s trying to hit a lot of the time that being said though the more manic and screamed vocal passages on this cut are just as intense as any on this lp so vocally speaking it&#39;s not like this track is a total dud and the other thing i&#39;d like to dive into at least a little bit with this track is the storytelling which seems to be about a trippy or life-threatening reaction to a bunch of food a captain fed to his crew like the boxing match there is sort of an old world familiarity to the backdrop and to the setting of this story but it&#39;s retold in the most profoundly disturbing way possible so i do enjoy elements of this track as well but i will say i&#39;m a bit more enamored with these straight-up rock grooves and raw riffs of welcome to hell which i think is more of an homage to primus than i&#39;ve heard almost any band do over the past several years some elements of the song sound like they&#39;re straight off of frizzle fry sans the slap bass of course but we do get those tight drums those sour chords the barked lyrics many of which touch down on the violent and insane nature of a military mentality but that special black midi touch comes by way of the performance growing more and more chaotic as it progresses and some of the mountainous hits of horns and strings that come at certain points of the song the song still is a quaint cool down moment on the lp goes in more of a folk and western direction with some very lovely finger picking what sounds like dreamy pedal steel cameron is back on vocal duty but i think his more measured demeanor fits a lot better with the acoustics on this one he even manages to nail those ascending vocal harmonies around the midpoint to the track too from here the whole track transitions into this sleepy bed of storybook instrumentation birds chirping strings drowning it is pretty and it does effectively transition into the interlude point at the middle of the lp half time which is a a bit of a radio themed comedy relief piece so yes all that great all that good but i do think this portion of the song does drag on just just a touch but from here we move into a very strong second half for this lp the race is about to begin as handily the most insane song on this whole record at least in terms of the intensity of it anyway greep is on vocals again and he&#39;s leading what essentially sounds like jarring circus prague the vocals are mixed so goddamn loud and they are moving at the speed of a coked-up auctioneer with all these crashing riffs and drums and pianos just creating such a cacophony in the background there&#39;s even a theatrical little passage in the first third that sounds like something out of a vaudeville show the track is just pure sensory overload which makes the really dramatic and spotlit vocal passages on the back end of the song even more gratifying really a calm after the storm or oh it feels like finally going to sleep after a super rough night that went into the wee hours of the morning the fire on this lp continues on to dangerous liaisons which instrumentally may not be as dizzying as race but there is a really strong and interesting narrative coming off of this one it&#39;s a story of a farm hand who is paid to murder a man strangle him to death i&#39;ll leave the spoilers for the track there but still what a dark and strange moment on this project and also just a testament to greek storytelling abilities as at least i found myself hanging on every single word the defense is a refreshing change of pace as i think this one is the most ballad-like cut on the entire lp very straightforward as well in terms of its chord progression and its structure instrumentally this is a pretty grand moment on the lp as well with greep&#39;s vocals kind of locking in with these massive string sections soaring off into the sky like he&#39;s some kind of a bizarro lounge singer three minutes though for a moment that is this sweet on an album that is this harrowing does seem a tad bit scant though i think the finale of this one could have been pushed a little bit further even if it does come to a pretty tight close and the song 27 questions ends things off strong with another helping of the same harrowing bitter avant prague that has painted much of the tracklist so far topped with more surreal extravagant and also cd imagery in the lyrics with what i think are at least a few narrative callbacks to tracks prior on the lp i wouldn&#39;t be surprised if all or many of the songs here tie together uh conceptually in some way but either way there&#39;s a pivotal moment on this track where the protagonist breaks into song in the song in a very lovely and quaint way it&#39;s not quite 27 questions the most hideous passages of aggressive and pounding instrumentation on the entire record to finish things off like really honestly the finish of this lp is just not [ __ ] the [ __ ] around and damn like what a great and hard-hitting creative bold colorful uh dizzying and overwhelming series of tracks from black midi uh even better than the batch of songs again in my opinion than they offered on cavalcade like not only better in terms of instrumental ambitions songwriting lyrics but i think some of the influences they were really wearing on their sleeves on the last lp they&#39;ve really kind of morphed into their own thing they&#39;ve kind of like sucked those in and kind of turned them into something that feels more unique to them are there a few passages and tracks and ideas that i think pale in comparison to others and a little brief or maybe drag on yes but outside of that like nearly every section of this record is mind-blowing amazing boundary pushing and black midi should absolutely be proud of everything they&#39;ve done on this record because i think like not only are they doing experimental rock and progressive rock and every other thing they&#39;re referencing here like a huge service uh with an album this good but uh you know they&#39;re really like punching with the same force as the greats on this one as well and i think that&#39;s only going to become more title: Cave World
transcript: hi everyone crowthanymagtano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new viagra boys album caveworld this is the third full-length lp of sweden&#39;s own viagra boys within a matter of several years these guys have become one of the best and most enjoyable most fantastic most fun and interesting post punk bands on the scene but they did not gain their success at least in my opinion by being merely an exercise in nostalgia just merely holding to the genres more traditional forms as their grime cake productions sleazy lyrics and absurd sense of humor not only are pretty refreshing for this style but feel very specific to them and it&#39;s great to hear on this new lp not only is all of that stuff carrying over into this new batch of songs but on this thing we&#39;re also getting an expanded instrumental palette as well as some pretty conceptual lyrical themes with a lot of songs in the track list here focusing on the dysfunction of the human condition which of course is presented in the frame of the modern day with all of the paranoia and hatred and conspiracy theories that are spread across social media these days but that&#39;s also juxtaposed against this image of humanity as apes rudimentary life forms that were destined for the tragedy that we&#39;re currently in due to our origins which plays out on tracks like the cognitive tradeoff hypothesis which sees front man sebastian murphy ghoulishly theorizing about how we were kicked out of the trees like in the early days left to fend for ourselves and had to essentially develop other traits in order to survive there&#39;s even a point where he questions whether or not this change in evolution and cognition has anything to do with his uh suffering from add and with all the colorful tones cartoony vocals along with the super deep and murky drums and bass on this track which are incredibly groovy the song couldn&#39;t sound more like the weirdest gorillas recording that you&#39;ve ever heard some of these themes i was mentioning also turn up on the opener baby criminal which presents an idea that i think has gotten a lot of exploration as of late especially with the recent jump in mass shootings committed by very young men and yeah the song essentially asks how do you go from an innocent little baby to a a violent bloodthirsty young adult or adult this question is set to wailing saxophones driving dance beats and guitars that don&#39;t know whether or not they&#39;re trying to soundtrack a dance floor a noise rock concert at a small venue or like a surf guitar competition still it sounds awesome all the same there&#39;s also troglodyte which features one of my favorite instrumentals here with a driving beat and lots of quirky colorful bits of guitar and synthesizer this track sounds like it&#39;s cut from the devo playbook in the best way possible but this is also a very tense and kind of angry track about going crazy and violent but the contextual nods and the lyrics are a bit more specific and current talking about a guy who&#39;s sitting on his computer and writing about things that he hates thinking all the news is fake and how if these people were alive during the time of apes they would have been shunned out of you know the apes society is unevolved there&#39;s even a point on this record where sebastian murphy is embodying the mindset of one of these individuals specifically on the track creepy crawlers which is not so much a song as much as it is a rant about 5g and lizard people and adrenochrome and vaccines all set to a spiral of never-ending noisy rock instrumentation and yeah while it&#39;s not exactly catchy it is more intense and hilarious frankly than many of the other cuts here many of the ideas i&#39;ve been talking about so far come to a head on the closing track return to monkey which kicks off with this leave society be a monkey tagline and essentially advocates for a lot of these hateful and uh kind of out of control people to essentially uh separate themselves from society and go live in the jungle instead hey you hate getting vaccinated uh nobody nobody needs to get vaccinated in the jungle where sebastian says they spend their time throwing [ __ ] at each other hanging out and masturbating the blistering noise rock passages to continue past this point are of course exhilarating and stellar and i absolutely love the measured spoken word outro for the song and the record as a whole which makes the album and everything it&#39;s about feel like a social experiment of some sort that has now gone awry and it&#39;s getting shut down reset cleaned off all for things to play out maybe the same way again which again is kind of an interesting and somewhat twilight zone-esque note to end on now outside of this there are some other deep cuts and singles on the record that i think are quite good be it ain&#39;t no thief which is a track that&#39;s all about aggressively thrusting off these allegations of having stolen something even though the items in question and the scenarios they were acquired in are so oddly specific they had to have been stolen this track also features one of my favorite instrumentals on the lp it kind of sounds like uh something out of a chase scene from a 1970s cop movie well wicka wow look at what we&#39;re like the dirtiest post-punkiest funk ever there&#39;s also punk rock loser who&#39;s very slow pacing when i first heard it didn&#39;t exactly win me over but the loose messy grooves and deadpan swagger have worked their charms on me as i&#39;ve revisited the song again and again and lyrically the track is really just a perfect mix of charisma and also self-deprecation and i like that these two elements are blended so finely and so aggressively you really can&#39;t tell like where the track lands on that spectrum the whole thing is so half-hearted in its performance it&#39;s like it&#39;s trying to unachieve but the fact that it doesn&#39;t give a [ __ ] is what makes it so attractive there&#39;s also big boy which is a very odd and kind of lo-fi moment on the album with some acoustic guitars in the background a a bunch of looping cycling drum beats some tongue-in-cheek falsetto harmonies on the chorus too the whole track sounds like a freaky hip-hop 90s singer-songwriter jam which i think is the best kind of detour for this album at this point uh even with it being a bit of a love song in a way if you could kind of interpret it to be so with it uh having his twisted presentation as it does there&#39;s also jason williamson of sleepered mods fame on the back end of the track doing one of his trademark rants which i think is a perfect addition to the song and then we have add which i think is the most electronic sounding track on the record with its persistent drum and synth sequences a lot of the track is about the inability to focus the cute and simple dance groove along with the sort of sloppy keys make it sound like it&#39;s trying to be a tongue-in-cheek club hit the more electronic aesthetics also fit with lines like i hope they replace my brain with a computer and flow-wise the track serves as a nice calm before the storm of the fiery closer i&#39;m not really sure what to say about this album past this point other than i am really impressed with it on multiple levels be it the production the instrumentation the overall performances specifically the vocal performances the writing and concepts spread across the record too how tight and fantastically flowing the track list is it&#39;s really all killer no filler and even the interludes on the project are effectively applicated this is handily the best project yet in my opinion from viagra boys it&#39;s maybe my favorite rock record so far this year and it&#39;s really everything i&#39;ve loved about the band up until this point turned up to [ __ ] 11. sure there are some tracks here that don&#39;t play as effectively into the more conceptual notes of the album as well as other tracks do and there are some parts that i think come off a little samey in terms of the drum grooves or maybe even the vocals like i think the record in in some ways could be a tad bit more versatile but honestly that&#39;s the extent of my complaints with this record it kicks ass i love it i think it&#39;s fantastic i&#39;m mega mega mega impressed with it and i&#39;m going to be sitting on this one and digesting it for a while i&#39;m feeling a strong nine on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next the channel anthony fantano viagra boys forever

title: Baby
transcript: hi everyone the supreme court is trash here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new petrol girls record baby this is the third full-length album from london-based rock outfit petrol girls first time hearing their stuff here and honestly uh pretty quickly listening to this i was blown away as this is truly a record for our current times in terms of tone messaging and righteous anger such a heavy forward-thinking and versatile sound for a punk album too as stylistically this record very much has a foot in the old and the new of course with this being a punk album from the uk petrol girls are very easily able to tap into that snide crass snotty tone that some of the best bands from that country have but by that same token the band seems equally as indebted to the american riot girl movement in terms of their mid-paced rifts sass and feminist rage occasionally the angular rips and leads on this thing read like something from a 2000s era post hardcore lp2 and on top of that the production on this thing is sick these tracks are laced with gargantuan and very rough guitar tones very intense vocal performances too that range from melodic like with the urgent and soaring vocal harmonies on the track fight for our lives or the explosive closing moments of feed my fire so there is versatility there but also this isn&#39;t a super long record either nothing really overstays its welcome with this thing clocking in at 34 minutes this lp is essentially trying to hit you with a bold and thoughtful message in as fast a time as possible and pounds it in hard with drums and guitars that are pushed to the limit just to make sure that you get it now sometimes it&#39;s also just the width displayed on these tracks that catches me like with the opening bars on the song preachers there&#39;s a lot of preachers but i don&#39;t see no saints a lot of fingers pointing palms sweating under red paint you know the idea of being caught red-handed but also being the accuser but yeah essentially an excellent reflection on public condemnation damnation and lack of nuance as a theme is also explored on the track one or the other presenting these rigid dichotomies as if someone must either be a victim or an abuser a man or a woman themes of division also play out on the song clowns too and i think there&#39;s a lot that can be gleaned out of the cutting lyrics and devastating snark on this track about existing in an ignorantly blissful dream of good intentions and adopting centrism as a political safe space out of a need to not be controversial or not be uh rubbing people the wrong way going against the grain meanwhile in our authoritarian times as this record says that&#39;s just allowing the bastards to run the place now if you&#39;re looking for an even bolder statement on this lp you have the track baby i had an abortion between the droning distorted tones on this track and the heavy ass drums this thing hits as hard as something like out of swann&#39;s early discography or maybe an idol&#39;s album with calls of whose life are you pro who&#39;s do you want to control meanwhile the gang vocals on the hook of baby i had an abortion and these snarling guitar leads are fantastic that proclamation being made in a mocking tone and in such a way to where it&#39;s sure to anger any pro-lifer which i think is necessary given that the verses illustrating the absurdity of their position will go over their heads then the song unsettled is a really interesting reflection on love and relationships rather than settling we are unsettling topically exploring modern romance as if it is a mold or a category to fall into with restrictions with lyrics mentioning wanting to be held but not held back it&#39;s a powerful statement on the ways in which love can be restricting even paralyzing if not engaged in in a way that is equitable and healthy though there also seems to be this nagging fear of of commitment and things kind of breaking off and failing at some point and wanting to finish things prematurely in order to avoid that the next two tracks on this lp feature vocals from janie starling a feminist organizer and former vocalist of the band dream nails the first of these two tracks fight for our lives features these heavy just crushing industrial guitar tones and drums which i think is very fitting for the song because it sounds like a goddamn war definitely a response to current times and the ongoing systematic violence against trans people sex workers undocumented women violent by design is your classic punk cops or [ __ ] screed i think it shouldn&#39;t be news to anyone that they are not here to protect you they&#39;re here to protect power as an institution the groovy drums and riffs on this track have almost a 90s alt rock feel to them but done so much harsher and more aggressively i also love the quirky girly vocal breakdowns that pop in here and they&#39;re there to make us safe keep us in our place criminals must pay so do what they say and yeah i&#39;m loving the bounce back and forth between the poetic sarcasm and also the enraged lead vocals that are just making salient points and asking the right questions sick and tired is essentially an all-of-the-above run-down of everything weighing down on the band from health issues to backaches to no breaks having to constantly protest against injustice and violence against women dealing with fake allies that don&#39;t actually have their best interests at heart keep in mind as i&#39;m running through these tracks and the various topics they dive into drums riffs vocals performances writing across the board is all killer kick-ass detailed heavy colorful textured truly more going into this punk record than most and with the closer bones we have a more epic finish than you would expect from most punk lps with grand group chorus harmonies calling out take away the noise and i am bones built the rhythms of my life on all this which reminds me of the sometimes cinematic grandiosity that you might get off of a [ __ ] up album when they were at their creative and conceptual peak back in the day though i&#39;ve never been much for [ __ ] up however i do enjoy this quite a bit but yeah overall i thought this was a kick ass and necessary album some of the most fiery punk i&#39;ve heard in a while and damn i just reviewed this freaking soul glow record too the most major issue i had on any single track here was probably on feed my fire where the transition into the more melodic vocal passages is a bit awkward not only that but the melody itself is odd and kind of slippery and i&#39;m not really sure if even the band itself has that tight of a grip of it but the intensely performed guitars and drums still are a treat especially toward the finish but yeah i love this thing i love the hell out of this thing uh once again found it super impressive on first listen and as i dove into it further and further and further it just kind of kicked more ass and said more very pertinent things and i hope you guys can take away as much from it as i currently am i&#39;m feeling a light too decent nine on this one tran position have you given this record a listen did you love it did you hate it but would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head it&#39;s another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano petrol girls forever

title: Diaspora Problems
transcript: hi everyone realty punk tano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new soul glow album diaspora problems this is the fourth full-length lp from east coast punk outfit soul glow their first for epitaph records and comes after a series of hardcore leaning eps that introduced me to the band&#39;s music over the past couple of years causing me to go into their back catalog which honestly has very much been a treat it was just one of those moments where i was like [ __ ] what have i been missing out on because i most definitely would have heaped praise onto their last full-length lp had i heard it because even in the raw state that their earlier releases are my god this is just some punishing hardcore the performances are so completely out of control unhinged and in a way reminds me of what the genre was at its peak in the 80s the aggression feels less calculated the intensity of the sound less indebted to how loud the production is and is more due to how wild the playing is which again reads like many early classic discord record releases as well as the early stuff of suicidal tendencies or even bad brains however i have to say diaspora problems is not just some exercise in hardcore nostalgia because punk is often a genre that can be obsessed with its past to a fault which can lead to stuff like gatekeeping as well as favoring sonically a tradition over progression but that is very much not a problem on this record in fact the way soul glow combines elements of hardcore indie noise and screamo is pretty refreshing plus they&#39;re not exactly shy about suddenly breaking into a song that has more hip-hop leanings too i should also praise the songs on this record too because the songs are good take the opening track here for example which i know listening to it it&#39;s very easy to get whipped up in the speed and intensity of the whole thing but it actually takes a lot of thought about structuring and dynamics to write a song like this that is this long and firing on all cylinders almost the entire time and it doesn&#39;t get boring it doesn&#39;t get drab it&#39;s just like edge of your seat from start to finish from the bright and sort of jangly guitar chords that open the intro to the chugging breakdowns toward the end underneath refrains of who got me my ass who could be fast and i wouldn&#39;t gloss over the lyrics either they are an absolute shotgun blast of reflections on materialism violence insecurity societal pressures to give into normalized [ __ ] like some of the best hardcore bands of all time i think you&#39;ll find that soul glove has a lot to say a whole lot to say sometimes to the point where you know the the rhythm and meter of the vocals is kind of just thrown to the wayside because uh what&#39;s more important is just getting out this lyrical machine gun fire so next from here we have the song coming correct is cheaper which th they did not sample the think break on this song you know that popular sample that&#39;s made it in many a dance and hip hop song over the years it&#39;s been used so many times from it takes two to even the latest porter robinson record and now it is here on this completely enraged hardcore punk diatribe about constantly feeling judged and appraised and limited by the expectations of modern society there&#39;s even a point where the lyrics here become a devastating statement on like a generational dead end in terms of having hopes for the aspirations that your kids will have or the things that they&#39;ll achieve beyond you plus that line about eating the rich and tradition and habits coming connected to fine print that are that are being handed down to you like the social commentary on this record is thumb sucker continues to see the band throwing left hooks into the track list with some really rocking hardcore riffs and peppy horn sections that actually pair together really well [ __ ] up if true hits with some riffs that dabble in a little bit of crossover thrash topped with enraged lyrics about our broken political system that does not serve the majority of voters oh and the noisy death metal breakdown on the back end is really cool jump or get jumped i loved as a single it sounds just as sick in the tracklist too i would say the band is absolutely nailing this balance between these thoughtful songs that obviously have a lot of care and planning put into them but they deliver them in such a way that feels manic out of control and overwhelming dripanomics was another teaser to the record that was a little off-putting at first but the more i hear it the more it grows on me it&#39;s like this noise rap punk fusion that features a lot of bars a lot of flows that sound like asap ferg rapping off of a helium tank over a grimy trap beat laced with all of these like power electronics and feedback samples and the whole track is about selling and upselling height beast clothes and like you know designer stuff yeezy birkin nike all these name brands the mother mary rose feature is a perfect fit and overall it&#39;s just a very clever and novel funny topic idea for a song five years in my family tells a story of one&#39;s personal progression to punk and the way tragedy and difficult family dynamics can make it hard to come to certain realizations about yourself and your mental health like again when i say this album does a lot and is speaking to a lot it really is the grinding riffs and blast beats on the things i carry makes for another blistering moment even more searing are the lyrics which are packed with all this radical self-accountability describing a lot of personal toxic behavioral patterns over sinister guitar leads some spoken word passages from the featured artist on the track bearcat 2. all of which come together and make for a very visceral but dark combination we want&#39;s revenge is probably the most cut and dry track on the entire lp it doesn&#39;t get more explicit than blaring riffs and screamo vocals that are doubled up and so hard hitting it gives blood brothers old stuff a run for its money i wouldn&#39;t say there&#39;s a whole lot of gray area in the lyrics too the final moments of this record refuse to sink into something that&#39;s run of the mill john jay&#39;s relentless drums and frightening noise core riffs are great even if at points the lyrics may be a bit much in terms of just scrambling to get it all out still the breakdown and demonic chorus vocals around the midpoint and the build and feature the song delivers from there is great god bless you all real good hits with a bit of a narrative switch as uh topically i would say this song is diving pretty deep into some very personal and very petty drama i mean it&#39;s not as if hardcore doesn&#39;t have a tradition of embracing narratives of betrayal it definitely does but man this very long-winded story about friends or or rather ex-friends it goes it&#39;s explosive it hits hard but i also feel like i&#39;m i&#39;m kind of reading an endless like twitter thread of just like people who know each other going at each other&#39;s thrones we then from here have the closer a spiritual level of gang [ __ ] where soul glow kind of takes the whole lp out on a sort of mellow hip-hop vibe with really spacey instrumentation some pretty solid features from mckinley dixon as well as logee for the first half i would say this track is a little average instrumentally though outside of the pummeling hardcore riffs popping in here and there to transition us from one section to the next am i blown away by it no but i will say it&#39;s still better than the vast majority of punk rap fusions i&#39;ve heard over the course of my lifetime and i lived through the 2000s plus the whole thing comes to a massive finish with really heavy horn sections and a refrain that brings a sense of togetherness which i think is a nice change of pace from all of the uh you know division intention going on in many of the narratives across the record up to this point [ __ ] what a good ass [ __ ] punk record my god like again performances writing riffs messaging production songwriting everything is just on [ __ ] point the versatility and creativity too the fact that this band stared right in the face the difficulty the challenge of modernizing and updating in in a great way like one of the most tried and true like stylistically black and white genres of underground music and just thwarted that just completely overcame that problem with no hesitation whatsoever even though there are spots of the record that i think are just a little over the top just doing a bit too much combined with the fact that the track list does fall apart a bit in terms of cohesion toward the end still with all of that like man this thing is mind-blowing it&#39;s great it&#39;s amazing it&#39;s fantastic this was easily one of my most anticipated albums of the year and it met my expectations and went far beyond them as well really blew them out of the water for the most part i&#39;m feeling a decent two strong nine on this one tran position have you title: God Don't Make Mistakes
transcript: hi everyone drama channel here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new conway the machine record god don&#39;t make mistakes this is a brand new lp from rapper and buffalo native conway the machine an important notch in his growing artistic belt his debut album for eminem&#39;s shady records considering that and the fact this record has been pushed back a little bit there&#39;s been a lot of anticipation for it with many fans including me assuming conway would go all out for this one and he did but not in the obvious way that a lot of artists may for a record like this like of course there are some big names on this lp like lil wayne rick ross ti there&#39;s production in the mix from a lot of griselda mainstays but also hit boy as well as the alchemist and justice league but the most striking thing about god don&#39;t make mistakes is how revealing it is some of the most memorable moments from conway&#39;s last high-water mark from king to a god were the most introspective and the machine digs in even deeper on this lp plus some of the best crossovers on this thing are either the most familiar or the most unlikely of course there&#39;s john wu flick with benny the butcher and west side gun where they just continue to bring that next level grimy chemistry and nail that down in only the way these three guys can there&#39;s also drum work which of course is named after conway&#39;s label and features more familiar faces j skis and love the genius and they bring two of the best features they&#39;ve done with conway so far now the extraordinary talent that is jill scott is featured on this record too not just with a song but a wrapped feature which plays the other side of a love connection being portrayed on chanel pearls and it&#39;s easily one of the best here like the flow is great the lyrical detail is there it locks into the greater narrative of the song perfectly and when jill breaks into those melodic lines on the back end of her appearance it&#39;s like not only amazing but it&#39;s two features in one keisha plum&#39;s intro on the song babis is surreal and sexual mesmerizing and conway&#39;s mother&#39;s vocals are featured on the final track of the record in in a way i won&#39;t completely uh spoil here but they are legitimately heart-wrenching and contribute to a very strong finish on this lp which thematically ties back to a lot of bars and ideas throughout the rest of the record which makes me have to point out that god don&#39;t make mistakes is conway&#39;s most holistic project yet in terms of consistency and vision the intro cut lock load creeps in with one of the most murderous instrumentals on the entire lp the droning synth chords the somewhat mushy rhythm guitars the first vocals on the track are conway commenting on how spooky the vibe is on this one and i have to agree 100 there&#39;s a smoky tone to his voice on this one like he&#39;s trying to keep uh what he&#39;s rapping about a secret which of course only enhances his entrancing flow his deadly bars sound like an endless nightmare and end where a very complimentary beanie siegel feature begins now beanie&#39;s inclusion on this track and this record is actually genius and reinforces the greater themes of this lp in a lot of ways because beanie and conway are each victims of gun violence and in both instances it impacted their careers and performance in significant ways that and the violent horrors being lyrically portrayed on this track make it almost a mirror of the closer that sees conway kind of quietly contemplating what if what if he had made different choices on that day that he was shot decided to be in a different place with a different person how would things have panned out would he be where he is today later in the track list we have piano love which is pure conway in pretty much every single way from the creepy fragmented pianos the fat beats just unadulterated lyrical nastiness hollow tips having your girl sneak a gun in for you in her large bag crack bars that are so detailed they&#39;re almost freaking confessional he said it&#39;s spooky things begin to mellow out in the tracklist on the song wild chapters which sees conway reflecting on the traumatic events and egregious behavior that he needed to transcend to get to where he is today he flows so effortlessly over this track as well in terms of like narrative and wording it sounds less like he&#39;s rapping less like a verse and more like a spoken monologue t.i and novel also do a great job on the track of reinforcing the songs themes of personal growth and perseverance a great hit boy beat on this one too that features these uh little cycling melodies quietly playing in the background like a tune that you would hum to yourself there&#39;s a beautiful nostalgia to this track that hits really deep as well which i would say is is also the case uh for the following guilty that has all these gorgeous keys and uh pitched soul chops in the beat many of the bars on this one read like a frank meditation on the ways having gotten shot has infected impacted conway from the bell&#39;s palsy to numbness in his legs and sort of seeing the comments and reactions that that has gotten online and what more can you say it&#39;s like great rapping it&#39;s great performance it&#39;s great writing and conway is delivering with the confidence and the clarity of like jay-z and his prime in the mid-2000s they&#39;re stressed which is obviously about stress this is conway&#39;s biggest emotional vent on any song ever kind of starts off typical in a way for a rap song working this angle he&#39;s stressed due to the pressure on him all the attention uh people who are not really taking his emotions seriously and asking for handouts left and right but then very quickly from here we move deeper into conway coping with a depression addiction the death of his son the suicide of his cousin it&#39;s absolutely positively in every way that it can be just devastating if you don&#39;t feel for this guy after this track i don&#39;t know what to tell you like man the final moments on this lp aren&#39;t all doom and gloom though and in some ways conway&#39;s push to be understood as a multi-dimensional person on the song so much more is even more moving as he demands to not just be pigeonholed as a rapper or even just a stereotype of a rapper cause on this track he raps about his humanity his charity his heart his perspective which is obviously at this point in his career really admirable the ways in which he&#39;s been able to geniusly navigate the music industry to grow his profile but also maintain an incredible amount of artistic freedom from here the luxurious and romantic chanel pearls is a great change of pace once more that jill scott features fire and again the closing track brings things full circle on this lp in such a powerful way now in my opinion there are a few weak points in the track list but i think they&#39;re pretty relative these cuts do have some decent moments despite some flaws namely tear gas with lil wayne and rick ross i think this track features a pretty good showing lyrically from everybody involved but everyone&#39;s respective energy just is so separate and compartmentalized there isn&#39;t really a super strong chorus bringing it all together either i think the rick ross verse on the back end feels almost tacked on after such an insane verse from wayne again good production good performances but the structure isn&#39;t the best and i think it kind of sticks out like a sore thumb given just how cohesive narratively and conceptually pretty much every other song here is especially with the other features that are in play then i think the song babas is a bit of a tough sell as well again while i love that keisha plum intro it&#39;s after that things begin to trail off with conway i think trying to write and deliver in a similarly fragmented and abstract style with a bit of a demonic chorus effect underneath his voice very subtly and i just don&#39;t know if like this direction is the best for him it comes off a little awkward doesn&#39;t really reach a strong conclusion either even though i do love the fact that this beat is the most nightmarish and strangest on the entire lp it&#39;s definitely a unique moment you know you can&#39;t say it&#39;s a just kind of a generic spot or just a track that blends in with everything else and in terms of the greater album flow it does provide an interestingly dark pocket just before this kind of self-affirming finish but that&#39;s kind of it for my complaints honestly like the vast vast majority of the material on this lp is the best conway&#39;s ever done he has outdone himself again his artistry and vision just continues to grow and i love it i&#39;m feeling a strong a to a light 9 on this one tran position have you given this record a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano conway the machine forever

title: Dragon New Warm Mountain I Believe In You
transcript: uh hi everyone tooth and emoji tano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new album from big thief dragon new warm mountain i believe in you what&#39;s it called dragon new warm mountain i believe in you a dragon a dragon what dragon new worm out and i believe in you you believe in the what dragon new warm mountain i believe in you a new magnet dragon dragon new war mountain i believe in you a heehee ha-ha dragon what a woodso dragon new warm mountain i believe in you it&#39;s a brand new album from indie folk and indie rock outfit big thief their fifth to date if i remember correctly and it&#39;s been a minute since we&#39;ve heard from the band like many groups on the indie circuit during the pandemic big thief pretty much laid low during much of that time who could blame them without the ability to tour on top of that they kind of spoiled fans in 2019 with two records released in that year the second of which left a far more positive impression on me than the first front woman adrian lanker also dropped two sister solo albums in the year 2020 that were pretty great james and buck members of the band also kept pretty busy with their own solo material too but now they&#39;re back in big thief mode obviously and it seems they wanted to make a big return with 20 whole new tracks on this record which i was kind of hesitant going into because i i do like big thief but do i 80 minutes like big thief plus albums of this size tend to be super thematic and conceptual and there&#39;s a whole series of risk factors that come into play with that but in a way i was refreshed to find that dragon new warm mountain is a double album that feels almost half its length the record&#39;s actually kind of fun and maybe even a little easy to listen to as end to end it&#39;s packed with all these punchy and direct blends of indie folk folk rock art country with a few semi-psychedelic experiments in the mix too in many ways i think this lp takes off from where big thief left us on their two hands record but kind of dives into that direction as boldly as they possibly can this lp also strikes a really good balance between consistency and variety featuring some of big thief&#39;s best songs to date too like spud infinity red moon and blue lightning all of which are really wild backwater country and folk with lots of colorful backing instrumentation linkers vocals provide a smart and kind of eccentric twang to the whole thing meanwhile songs like simulation swarm the only place in certainty feel a lot more modern pulling from some classic indie folk acts such as elliott smith modest mouse bonnie prince billy especially in the rhythm section and guitar work not to mention 12 000 lines is just about the best joni mitchell warship i&#39;ve heard in a minute for simplicity&#39;s sake we also have some very stripped back acoustic cuts that could have fit on linker&#39;s last couple of solo records dried roses promises a pendulum of course on these tracks linker&#39;s vocals and unique lyricism shine like the communication and emotional blocks on promise being likened to hearing fantastically quiet things or impossibly building these natural wonders such as rainbows or a meteor shower these pockets of the record contrast nicely of course with moments where they&#39;re diving into some really rich sonic experimentation like time escaping for example the quirky arpeggios and lo-fi beet loops on this one create a total groove gasm which gives way to these heavenly rushes of vocal harmonies and flower of blood is a pretty effective combination of indie folk aesthetics and hazy 90s shoe gaze in my opinion meanwhile the subtle and dusty lo-fi drums and eerie ringing keys and guitars on blurred view really crawl into your brain stem along with adrian&#39;s vocals being so close they&#39;re almost asmr and i have to mention wake me up to drive the peppy casio drum machine beats on this one along with the accordion sound like the result of some kind of random instrument generator but big thief somehow makes it work sounding like one of the coolest and weirdest open mic title: Ants From Up There
transcript: uh hi everyone anthony fantano style here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this black country new road record ants from up there this is a new lp from uk rock outfit black country new road quickly following up their beloved debut from last year for the first time which was met with a very warm reception far surpassing the high expectations that fans had of it based on early singles like sunglasses and science fair for the first time may have not been a perfect record but it was so good overnight black country new road pretty much went from a band to watch to one of the best and most exciting the underground had to offer currently with inventive and refreshing combinations of post punk art experimental and post rock not to mention some of the klezmer bits on this record too which were amazing the band also featured the one-of-a-kind vocals and lyricism of isaac wood whose writing and performances were so intensely anxious and detailed that undoubtedly if you came across a black country&#39;s music over the last year so he made an impression on you good or bad now tragically isaac announced his departure from the band just days before this album was set to be released it seems to have been an amicable split with the band saying they plan to continue creatively past this point yes it&#39;s an unfortunate change but at least for now we have this recording this new recording for black country new road uh still in one piece and at the very least on this record they answer the question of whether or not for the first time was merely a fluke beginner&#39;s luck cause once again on this album i&#39;d say the band surpassed expectations hard last year i did an interview with band members lewis evans and tyler hyde and one thing i did glean from it was that they were really excited about the directions that the new music was taking on this record and having heard it now i can see why this thing rests a lot harder on the wide array of instrumentation that the band has access to outside of the baseline of guitars and drums horns pianos synth and violin play a much larger role on this project and not only is this project more versatile instrumentally but it pulls from a larger pool of influences i think too no longer can haters dismiss black country new road simply as a slint rip-off as dumb as that point was to begin with this new lp sports touches of minimalism and prague jazz mixed with the raw emotional chaos of early bright eyes as well as the rock elegance of groups such as talk talk plus the grandiose indie anthemics of wolf parade and arcade fire but just like with for the first time this record isn&#39;t so much about its influences as much as how creatively and uniquely they&#39;re brought together with dynamic performances and passionate writing from end to end pretty much every teaser to this record to one degree or another was fire and the band dropped so many tracks they left very little up to the imagination when the entire thing dropped but still this whole record comes together fantastically the intro on this thing is a tight short instrumental piece in five with bright horns and a loud chaotic finish the track contains a harsh beauty that sets up the theatrical chamber rock of chaos space marine perfectly this song is maybe the closest we&#39;re going to get to an indie rock opera this year the tense beds of pianos and string and guitar are wonderful and really make the vivid imagery in isaac&#39;s lyrics come to life especially during the jubilant chorus so i&#39;m leaving this body and i&#39;m never coming home again i&#39;ll bury the axe here between the window and the kingdom of men jesus the track is so thrilling so edge of your seat so ergasmic even without it following a traditional song structure as instrumentally it just kind of keeps building up tension from here this track and many others on the lp show the band has such a firm grasp of tension and release the song concord after this sees the band tumbling further into forlorn poetic balladry packed with dynamic swells of horns and piano the lyrics here are made up of all of these moving and strange metaphors dealing in longing loss and departure in life and in love i&#39;m just so consistently impressed with isaac&#39;s writing i feel like the beauty of his word speaks for itself i came a gentle hill racer i was breathless upon every mountain just to look for your light but for less than a moment we&#39;d share the same sky and then isaac will suffer concord will fly it&#39;s a bittersweet moment on the record that leads into the incredibly despondent bread song whose instrumental swells like a gigantic orchestral lullaby many of the lyrics on this track seem to describe this unraveling social situation that concludes in this immense moment of rejection oh don&#39;t eat your toast in my bed oh darling i never felt the crumbs until you said this place is not for any man nor particles of bread which is i think a pretty sole uh crushing comparison uh to be made even if it is a little inadvertent the following goodwill hunting is one of those black country new road songs that i know some of the lyrics from it are gonna be stuck in my head repeating in my head for the next year because that was very much the case for multiple songs and lyrical highlights from the last record she had billy eilish style moving to berlin for a little while trying to find something to hold on to the story of the song has this odd mix of awkwardness and hope that i get off of a lot of great and very genuine talking head songs but obviously black country comes to much different instrumental conclusions the story that isaac is telling here is so idyllic and storybook in a way but his wording here makes it clear that what he&#39;s saying is something he&#39;s merely musing about fantasizing about and there&#39;s a sadness to that especially as he launches into this diatribe about how he&#39;d bend over backwards to keep himself in the mind of this other person who he&#39;s singing about traveling through space to get home to them another stellar instrumental performance on the track too even though this song features a more standard song structure the varying beds of instrumentation keep every section of it feeling fresh and new there&#39;s more instrumental magic to follow too on the song haldern i love the repeating minimal horn and piano lines that the song here floats on top of which contrasts nicely with the heavy crunchy guitar riffs in between next mark&#39;s theme is a touching and beautiful little saxon piano piece that effectively works as a palette cleanser before we&#39;re hit with the biggest tracks on the entire record in the last leg now the three cuts this record closes out with pretty much make up half the entire album the place where he inserted the blade which sounds like spencer krug and connor oberst in their prime collaborating on the most grandiose and depressing song they could possibly conceive finishing off as well with these huge group vocals this track in a lot of ways feels like an extension of the cutting and depressive balladry that much of the record has been made up of so far but everything about it is pushed to the brink instrumentally and emotionally meanwhile the song snow globes a nine minute monster kicks off with these very patient plucked down stroked guitar lines with some subtle bass underscoring it sounds kind of like a classic post rock song from the 90s lift your black country like antennas to new road so even if these guitars are instantly recognizable in a somewhat derivative way very quickly we start getting uh these intense flurries of free jazz drumming coloring the whole thing actually coloring might be the wrong word smothering because the drums are so damn loud and mixed so aggressively which even though there are elements of the song i do love uh might make for my least favorite part of this entire record i feel like i&#39;m experiencing the final crescendo of this track from inside one of the toms i do have to give it to the band though because the gradual progression and performance of the entire track is still great then basketball shoes is the multi-phase 12-minute grand finale for the entire record with the sad twangy midwest emo guitar lines coloring the intro the passionate sax lines that build on top of it lyrical themes of decimation and concord return the song somehow becomes even more emo influenced during a riff switch up at the midpoint really everything like from the drums the guitars the lyrics but isaac&#39;s vocals and the extra layers of instrumentation keep this track feeling like it&#39;s firmly in line with everything else on the record consistent the distorted crescendo is ergasmic the uh heavy sax rock outro is amazing the group vocals come back once more one of the best lyrical highlights hits at the very end of the record too your generous loan to me your crippling interest every single song has like some heart wrenching soul destroying burning just like ah it hurts but yeah wow like just what a great record man what a great impressive well-performed written and produced record from frankly a one-of-a-kind band very sad that uh you know things kind of panned out in the way uh that they did with the departure of isaac but uh once more at least we were able to as the audience share this moment with the band hear this music hear them at some kind of creative peak hopefully this unforeseen change doesn&#39;t really like you know kneecap uh the potential of the group going forward because uh this record is just stellar and if we were to lose you know black country new road uh after this moment that would be a quite the tragedy especially again considering how great this is i mean i i pretty much loved every single song on this thing to some degree there were some spots that ran a little lengthy or a derivative there&#39;s that you know mixing issue on snow globes i wasn&#39;t too nuts about but still i mean i i thought this thing was a uh just great feeling a decent two strong nine on this one tran position have you given this record a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano black country new road forever

title: Marchita
transcript: other boy tano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new sylvana estrada record marchita this is a brand new lp from mexican vocalist and songwriter sylvana estrada which follows her 2017 record with ciudad de los flores which was more of a latin jazz experience marchita however heads into more of a folk pop and chamber music direction with gentle lovely acoustic tunes topped with really expressive lead vocals whimsical melodies and occasionally some very ornate instrumentation too this thing is just 11 tracks in 37 minutes so not exactly the most intensive listen you&#39;re gonna have this year but sylvana still packs a lot of beauty and a lot of punch into these relatively short direct songs i like to think of them as little acoustic bouquets where sylvana shows a lot of dynamics and restraint for example the intro track masomenos antes really eases you into the record the opening moments instrumentally of this track are so soft you could hear a feather drop into a glass of water but when sylvana pulls out these just heart-wrenching vocal leads just really starts to push on the volume a little bit it cuts deep but again this track is just a taste just the start of the beauty that is going to continue to unfold through the rest of the track list the following track coriente turns the heat up a little bit with some minimal piano accompaniment along with these horns that sync up with sylvanas elegant lead vocals that tell us of these haunting metaphors dealing in the memory of someone in the ocean there&#39;s a tense captivating melancholy to the track that just gets a hold of me very quickly which is even more so the case for tiguardo that features these decimating passages of lyricless croons and weepy strings there&#39;s also this growing sense of unease in the track as this rising flood of piano and strings just builds underneath sylvanas vocals it just kills me the instrumentally ambitious sections of this record are pretty impressive but i&#39;m equally as captivated by some of the simpler spots too like the stomp clap vocal combo of undia cualquiera where sylvana brings a vocal performance that really fills up the open space and you gotta love the soap opera organs and vocal harmonies that bring such a nice a simple but strong climax in the end from here on the record we move into a pretty strong midsection sabre elvidar is a straightforward and again simple folk tune that has a three two four chord progression the soft and sweet guitars on this track are topped with some of the most decisive and authoritative singing and lyrics from sylvana on the record there&#39;s a lot of conviction to her performance on this track and i can hear why with all of her descriptions about desiring to let go of the past and forget about things in her past uh that are haunting her then when the baroque strings come into the mix like ugh i&#39;m melting i feel like i&#39;m having an out of body experience watching myself die in the most artsy tele novella ever the anguish the longing the haunting feelings of love and skin contact continue on to the title track which has some very flashy string arrangements then trista is uh i&#39;ll say this record is one of the most uh pretty portrayals of being down in the dumps i&#39;ve ever heard that being said i don&#39;t know if this track has the strongest progression of the bunch in the tracklist but it&#39;s still a nice listen and also leads us into the final leg of the lp and many of its lyrical themes for example on the song carter that desire to come back together seems to be replaced with the realization that hey maybe um you know uh uh you know rekindling this was a bad idea and that realization kind of brings a freeing and exciting tone to uh the song on this track the bright open landscapes of non-stop violin and aggressively strummed guitar very much feels like yay i&#39;m not caught in this miserable cycle forever yay meanwhile the first half of casa is like this fragmented sparkling bjork inspired meditation that eventually breaks into these massive and thick just dark dark dark dark dark passages of horns and strings then sarah de t is kind of an easy going note for things to end on again a very straightforward folk tune which features the very plain finger picking and middle of the road pacing that was sort of the mark of many indie folk tunes in the 2000s iron and wine fans would eat this up the upright bass and lazy groove on the track are a nice touch as well now narratively the song presents an interesting shift too as in a way it feels almost like an open letter to the other person telling them that hey you know what you you can come back when you like maybe maybe we&#39;ll try this again the emotional push and pull up this record is too much beyond that there&#39;s a beautiful horn outro on this record too that&#39;s quite touching i think uh given the narrative and just everything instrumentally that&#39;s gone on so far an instrumental ending i i think is very very fitting very smart because yeah this record does have good writing good instrumentation and production arrangements all that like all of these great boxes are just being like checked and checked and checked over and over and over but on top of that what makes this record special but it does so well is that it translates very directly very bluntly just like emotion right into sound bam you know you&#39;re getting your emotion right from that sound right from the melodies right from the dynamics of the instrumentation from the vocal performance in such a potent and again direct way but yeah track for track this is a really beautiful wonderful captivating uh lovely record would talk your ear off about it for 10 more minutes if i thought it made sense but look i i love this thing i think it&#39;s great easily going to be one of the best singer songwriter records of the year there were a couple tracks i felt paled in comparison to others but uh you know only by a very very very small degree feeling a light to decent nine on this one tran position have you given this record a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano sylvana estrada forever

title: KicK iii
transcript: um hi everyone destinyqueentano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a reviews of arca kicks two through five yes this is a brand new series of albums from singer producer songwriter rapper pianist visionary venezuela&#39;s own arca these albums serve as the highly anticipated follow-ups to her uh wonderful kick one album that dropped last year which saw her delivering inventive takes on artpop and latin pop a host of other things too i think arca&#39;s move into more vocal driven music and pop forms has been interesting to say the least especially since her sense of sonic adventure has not been lost in the process and that is especially true of this new batch of records which are a surprise in many ways after kick one we knew kik was going to be a musical series of some sort and it would come to an end eventually but i and many others had no idea all these records were going to collapse onto each other at the end of this year and on top of it an additional one kick five was added on to the list of announced albums so yes four brand new albums dropping all at once uh they range in a time span from like 34 minutes to 42 minutes so nothing too uh time consuming i suppose but all of these records uh range in style aesthetic and intensity i wrestled a lot with how exactly to engage with these projects in this review especially since yes they are separate works but simultaneously they do sort of reinforce each other a bit addressing each album separately in a vacuum in its own review i think wouldn&#39;t make total sense but attempting to rate them and analyze them as a whole doesn&#39;t really make sense either so here&#39;s my plan i&#39;m going to talk about all of these records in this one video in order from my least favorite in the series to my favorite in the series here we go okay so we&#39;re starting with kick 4 here like i said i&#39;m going to talk about these records from my least favorite to my favorite and yes it is true that kick 4 is my least favorite of all of these recently dropped records but that doesn&#39;t mean i don&#39;t like it for the most part i think it&#39;s a decent release kick 4&#39;s easily the dreamiest softest and most serene and melodic of these kik projects a lot of digitally enhanced androgynous croons laced into shimmering beds of synthesizers the song structures on this one are also a bit more loose making it easy for these songs to come together into maybe more of a holistic experience as opposed to looking at each track as an individual statement and over the course of this track list there are some stunningly beautiful highlights the way the breathtaking orchestrations and alien vocal leads intertwine on asuna xenomorph girl features some equally entrancing and wonderful vocal leads but this time paired with some much more mesmerizing beats and i also love the very curious and pitched strange and childlike lead vocals on the song the build of instrumental layers on lost women found are also beautiful but simultaneously make for one of the most immense and powerful moments on the lp as they get so thick and heavy so absolutely there&#39;s highlights on this lp but simultaneously there were some issues that i found as well as i revisited it for one some tracks melodically and structurally come off a bit too vague compositionally there&#39;s not a whole lot to hang on to and in terms of progression they sort of go nowhere fast some of the vocal performances on these songs as well i found to come off a bit too grating considering just how soft and easy going the backing instrumentation was which is especially true of tracks like a witch or even queer for example which uh i wish i liked that track more i appreciate it more in the track list than i did as a single i&#39;ve never really been a huge fan of planning to rock&#39;s vocals but i do you know understand uh what uh you know their significance is to an artist like arca and i think it&#39;s incredible that they crossed over here for sure for this project the song alien inside doesn&#39;t really seem to fit in with the rest of the mood and vibe too some of the harsh sound effects and very assertive spoken word passages uh do feel a bit heavy-handed so again kik4 i think has some really great highlights and i think overall it does achieve a certain aesthetic and stylistic focus for the most part anyway but the songs themselves i found to be kind of a mixed bag i&#39;m feeling a strong six on this one okay next i want to address kick 2 which stylistically i found to be more along the lines of what i was expecting from the kick series given what arca did on kik 1. and for the most part i think it&#39;s pretty on par with that record too kick 2 is also maybe the least conceptually and aesthetically focused of the kick records which seems pretty purposeful as many of the tracks on this thing i think can be digested as individual pieces as opposed to something a part of a larger hole this has led to a lot of tracks that are not only catchy hit hard but work well as singles this is especially true of the songs on this thing where arca finds herself bringing together elements of art pop and reggaeton much in the same way she did on klokay off of kick one with this very futuristic spaced out synth-heavy sound prada rakata tiro and luna yena all bangers in my opinion as i said when i heard kale okay originally i really could do an entire album of this i also find tracks like these to be some of the most necessary that arca does today in terms of a being at the forefront of crafting a sort of post-modern sound in in latin pop but also like kick one on kick two there are these other pieces that are a little short brief half baked and others that that i think defy any kind of conventional appeal sometimes to the point of absurdity like with the fragmented rhythms and warped synth leads on irania which sound almost like they&#39;re trying to parody themselves there are also a few tracks that don&#39;t really feel like they progress past a point of introduction lethargy is an example i love the way that this one flirts with these hip-hop forms and grooves but it just kind of feels too mild across the run of the track and doesn&#39;t really build up in any way significantly i will say this though originally i was not really crazy about born yesterday featuring sia as a single for this project but hearing it in the context of the record i enjoyed a lot more especially considering how much more i guess accessible it is than a lot of other stuff here and having heard an entire record of this style of production up to this point uh it does sort of solidify arca&#39;s you know imprint and influence on the song itself even if c is kind of dominating uh vocally on the track so while kik 2 i found to be a little all over the place and a bit inconsistent it is equal parts exhilarating and perplexing i&#39;m feeling a light seven on this one next let&#39;s talk about kick five probably the biggest grower for me in the kick series not only because it was added on later but it&#39;s easily the most understated of all the kicks if anything defines this album i think it&#39;s a minimal approach which for arca is certainly saying something since much of her music has this tendency to be very dense be very glitchy be very disorienting and difficult to wrap your mind around so how would an arca album sound if you stripped it back to musically its most basic and simplest elements the answer is pretty beautiful arca&#39;s knowledge of ambient textures and classical keys are on full display on this lp there are some tracks that run a little brief or fall into some of the same somewhat uh grating potholes that uh songs on kik4 did but the plucky glossy and classically influenced keys on estrogen are gorgeous as are the equally bare pianos on ether the cycling and increasingly distorted synth arpeggios on amrep not only remind me of the early work of aphex twin but are pretty mesmerizing too while tierno&#39;s gentle chords and lead vocals feel like a more fully realized version of what arca was doing on her self-titled record in 2017. a couple tracks on the back end see arca exploring more spacious textures the song la infinite does feel infinite to a degree with just this deep cavernous reverb soaking much of the instrumentation here but the composition at the core of it doesn&#39;t feel as grand as the space that it is locked into however i think fire prayer has a much more gratifying climax with some classical piano roaring through all of these tension building layers of synthesizers there are some slightly underwhelming moments here and while i do appreciate the more minimal direction and ambient direction of this record it does seem like arca kind of struggles to find a cohesive way to go about implementing that sound across the entire lp it&#39;s kind of like we get a little bit of a taste of it in one way here a little bit of another taste of it there i also think the somewhat glitchy closer feels like something that would have been more appropriate for kick two as opposed to five but overall i still found the vast majority of the tracks on this thing beautiful and uh thought that this record was easily one of the more compelling uh in the kick series i&#39;m feeling a decent two strong seven on this one i feel like i&#39;m speed running this review all right kick three easily my favorite of the kick records and one of my favorite records of the year as well what&#39;s funny is i love it so much and uh simultaneously i have a hard time putting this record into words but what is clear is this album hunkers down on a lot of the hip-hop influences club influences glitch influences and industrial influences that defined a lot of arca&#39;s early work from those stretch eps and stuff that she had done for like kanye west seasons so all those styles are in full effect here once again but now they&#39;re really really really being pushed to the brink in such a way where i think kick 3 is the most explosive visceral and show-stopping project arca has ever done really career defining in my opinion i think this record&#39;s an improvement on a lot of things for arca as well for one on the opener bruja arca&#39;s rapping abilities have solidified quite a bit since that first kick lp she sounds so great confident and charismatic on these fragmented clubby beats loaded with all of these harsh and dystopian perks the howling vocals and synthesizers over the bridge of the track as well make me feel like i&#39;m being possessed the following cut also hits some really high intensity points as well with a horrifyingly industrial twist on again these very club-friendly rhythms in many ways the song fiera feels like a futuristic step past all of these loose woozy wonky grooves that have defined so many classics off of the brain feeder records catalog meanwhile skull queen and elektra rex push the album&#39;s limits of hyperactivity speedy beats and jittery vocals and sound effects that feel like i&#39;ve just drank way too many energy drinks i&#39;m also reminded of richard d james a little bit uh in this portion of the record skull queen feels like i&#39;m listening to a classic aphex beat but with someone hyperventilating over it the track ripples features all these unsettling hyper wraps over some dizzying glitchy beats think of any number of tracks off of like sophie&#39;s wonderful project uh product but uh take everything that was disorienting about those songs and multiply it by 10. all the scuzzy distorted synthesizers and bits of percussion feel like binary code is being violently downloaded into my brain senorita is easily hands down the biggest and best industrial rap banger i&#39;ve heard this year death grips eat your [ __ ] heart out what a groove man the drums are massive and the glitchy enhancements on arko&#39;s vocals are incredible like this track among many others hits so hard and there&#39;s also this amazing attention to detail i was also surprised to see a co-credit from machine drum on the cut two from here we move into a pretty impressive final leg where arca continues the sensory overload experience all of the insane layers of vocal chatter in the second half of my two are equally maddening and exciting while intimate flesh is one of the most bassy and sensual cuts on the entire lp and speaks a lot to this album&#39;s overall themes of hedonism sex and sexuality i also find it interesting how the vocal layers on this one are very manipulated and pretty strange as well but they come together in a way that&#39;s more mesmerizing than they even are on some of the more subtle cuts in the kick series and with hoya i don&#39;t think i could have asked for a better calm after the storm of this entire record the song features a lot of very beautiful sparkling synth passages and some of the most angelic vocals on all of the kick records outside of maybe a few tracks not feeling as intense as others my mind was absolutely blown by this record from first listen and continues to be as i listen to it again and again and again this is my favorite of the kick albums and just an incredible feat for arca creatively i&#39;m feeling a decent two strong nine on this one and while i do feel the strongest about kick three that&#39;s not to totally single that project out as uh being way more superior than everything else here because i still do at the end of the day see it as a part of the kick series as a whole and i think all five of these albums coming together uh really assemble into an incredible era and body of work for arca uh that not only feels like you know a high point for her creatively but also has me really excited to see what the future for her music is going to be because she already sounds and feels so ahead of the curve in so many ways like what arca&#39;s music could possibly sound like over the next three to five years is just uh out of the realm of my imagination i think but yes some really incredible groundbreaking and significant work from arca in these records and uh incredible that she was able to come together complete all of these albums have all of them coming through with a distinct sound and personality and uh what she accomplished here is just really uh commendable regardless of what you know my or anybody&#39;s you know individual feelings are on uh any one
