title: Henki
transcript: hi everyone anthony cartano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of the new richard dawson and circle album henke this is a brand new lp from uk singer songwriter richard dawson who is teaming up with the finnish rock band circle on this new one an experimental and progressive band that&#39;s been putting out records since about the early 90s dawson actually teased this kind of surprising crossover in a recent interview i did with him uh where he said this new record would lean kind of progressive and and boy was he not lying i mean stylistically that&#39;s really uh circles bread and butter but dawson himself is no stranger to working loads of experimental and progressive influences into his very left field brand of folk music as well his last proper album the dystopian pre-pandemic prediction that he came out with in 2019 which was titled 2020 which i guess was just a little bit off in terms of predicting just how awful the immediate future would be it turns out the picture he painted could have just been a lot grimmer but instrumentally some of the tracks on this record were some of dawson&#39;s most rock inspired so far and there was also the uh lockdown album he came out with the republic of geordi land which had some pretty abstract but somewhat unrealized ideas all over it too so now from there we are on to this new record with circle and on it we pretty much get dawson&#39;s enchanting style of songwriting and very eccentric topic choices his strange but passionate lead vocals too backed now with a full nerd prague arsenal of guitars bass drums synths some electronics as well and the whole thing is fantastic featuring the seven lengthy tracks with intriguing stories packed into each of them i think this record also serves as a reminder of progressive rock&#39;s original mission not just to attain some certain level of technical proficiency but also to break and advance past the conventions of rock and popular music and while these seven tracks are quite anthemic and do sit on some tried and true tropes they&#39;re far from conventional the opening track cooksonia is titled after a genus of extinct land plants and is essentially a story about a botanist&#39;s upbringing and education then eventually leading to this tragic outing where they and another botanist are traveling with some specimens that are deteriorating as they leave the country the whole story of the song ending in this picture of desolation and of course the whole tale is soundtracked by these meditative and primal drums grim guitar strumming some sparkling synth passages too to break the tension not to mention the finish of the track escalates into this wall of psychedelic fuzzy folk and this song overall is a very easy going but emotional start to a record that gets more adventurous and urgent as it continues the song ivy for example is a multiverse epic that touches down on a few different narrative points of greek mythology but the whole thing seems mostly in reference to the seder silenus who eventually gives the power to turn whatever he wanted by touch to gold to king midas which if you&#39;re familiar with that story you know how tragically that ends and the music complementing this track is as dark grand and archaic as i could have hoped for especially in the first leg with it sounding like the soundtrack to a medieval dungeon plus i love that dawson hits us with these preposterous but uh kind of amazing falsettos the whole thing gets even better as the rhythms and riffs pick up around the midpoint where the story gets kind of treacherous around a stoning and some travel at sea the greek tie-ins continue on the record with the track silphium with mentions of apollonia and cyrene the story itself seems to feature merchants or travelers on a tiring journey where they are lost and running out of food or just not eating the best of food and outside of dawson&#39;s falsettos hitting a little weak on the front end the whole first leg of the track is a throttling thrill ride where the dire circumstances of the protagonists in the story translates really clearly in the middle of the track there&#39;s also a sudden jazz rock break that goes over really well with the original riffs and rhythms coming back for a finale on the back end cylene is a more meditative cut by comparison with everything else here with these very repetitive guitars and pulsating electronics and i appreciate the whole thing more in concept than i do in practice because there are multiple passages where dawson and circle throw on top of this rhythm section some vocal layers and melodies that seem almost at odds with the instrumentation below which i&#39;m sure to a degree was intentional as it is a bit jarring and everything else on the record is so cohesive by comparison but i&#39;m not really sure if the effect they were going for really came through but the last several songs on the record are some of the strongest here the plant themes on the lp continue with the track methuselah which is not only the name of one of the biggest sequoias on earth but the track also seems to be a story about donald rusk curry a researcher and geographer who was known for in the 60s having accidentally killed what&#39;s known to be the oldest living tree the lyrics of the track give a detailed description as to how this happened and then immediately after this realization hits him uh the whole thing breaks into this pandora&#39;s box of uh frightening refrains and riffs it gets really grim lily is probably the most straightforward and clean cut structurally on the entire lp the hook hits really hard on this one and with immediacy now don&#39;t get me wrong some of the group vocals on this thing are pretty theatrical and campy and dawson&#39;s falsettos won&#39;t be for everybody it is weird but it&#39;s still quite catchy even with some of the operatic vocals on the bridge and the lyrics being as morbid as they are then the closing track i really enjoyed i thought was a rockin and triumphant finish for the whole thing comes to a really amazing vocal and instrumental climax toward the end too with a circle really going absolutely insane really making some of the most wild and raw prague music i&#39;ve heard in a while i mean yeah i&#39;m i&#39;m heavily impressed with this record it&#39;s so good the songwriting the production the performances it&#39;s just all great so full of personality so colorful and uh and so unique lyrically and conceptually i think dawson hits it out of the park once again and it just so happens that circle was the perfect accompaniment to the whole thing i&#39;m feeling a strong eight to a light nine on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head it&#39;s it&#39;s another video you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano richard dawson forever

title: LP! [Offline Version]

singer songwriter the left-wing hades a.k.a jpeg mafia following up the beloved 2019 record all my heroes are cornballs which saw a modest shift in peggy&#39;s style toward more pop and r b melodies and while i did prefer his breakout record veteran to that one he still continued to push forward artistically on some subsequent eps ep1 and ep2 the former of which contained some of his best bangers to date then the latter had more mellow melodic cloudy cuts on it that have come together into one of my favorite eps of the year and then there&#39;s lp which in my opinion feels like artistically everything peggy has been honing up until this point experimental abstract lo-fi hip-hop glitch hop with again now more touches of pop and r b and now peggy&#39;s even whipping up beats that have more of a hardcore hip-hop flavor or rock flavor to them his versatility continues to amaze but what i love even more about this project is that he&#39;s recaptured that unpredictable energy that made veterans such a guessing game for me and many other fans it should also be noted that there are two versions of this project too a version you can find on just about every streaming service out there and a more offline version that&#39;s floating around bandcamp right now both versions feature different tracks different track lists some tweaked instrumentals or song structures i i assume because of like sample clearance reasons the differences between these projects aren&#39;t night and day but they are there and while the streaming version does have bops on it like bald and cutie pie i see those more as ep 1 cuts anyway and ultimately tracks like hazard duty pay from the offline version are kind of highlights that i wouldn&#39;t want to go without now i will say the streaming version does have its merits too this version of the project is more concise which is not a bad thing and on top of it the ghost of ranking dread with its very grim and shimmering wall of synthesizers and guitars at the end brings a greater sense of finality to the end of the record if we&#39;re you know taking songs like cutie pie and bald as mere extras and i also think damn damn damn makes more sense in the middle of the lp than toward the end too once more i prefer the offline version that&#39;s the one it seems that peggy had to change around or alter the least but whatever one you want to listen to is whatever so in my opinion lp&#39;s most exciting qualities are that it is volatile and versatile sonically and emotionally this thing is difficult to pin down in only the way that peggy&#39;s music is right now at one point on this record he says these days the bar so low for weird [ __ ] i had to stop sharing which is absolutely true even truer white boys beyond a burner so they think they scared but really the risk-taking and the weirdo attitude that peggy exudes on this record is just so unparalleled and that&#39;s been the case for a while but i think it becomes even clearer as a result of lp being out and what&#39;s funny is this record is so odd it&#39;s so out there and it&#39;s filled with so many unlikely combinations of sounds and ideas and yet it&#39;s still so incredibly catchy and there are tons of moments on this thing that stick with me even after an initial listen whether that&#39;s the opening track trust which is loaded with these uh feel-good rhymes with a chill delivery floating on top of these twinkling hyperactive synthesizers it kind of sounds like a beat that you&#39;d find on some obscure soundcloud producers page that&#39;s packed with anime images and that together with peggy&#39;s voice makes for an incredible contrast of energies there are also loads of memorable bars on the second verse of the second track dirty where peggy is taking down very pointedly trend dependent artists their filler lines their tacky production and doing it all over these glitchy synthesizers these industrially tinged heavy rhythms the whole beat sounds like peggy made it on a [ __ ] lathe then nemo was so harsh and preposterous sonically and lyrically i i don&#39;t know how i couldn&#39;t be in awe of it the track makes most glitch hops sound normal and there are plenty of other spots on this lp that are incredibly smooth and accessible like with the luxurious r b instrumentation and soaring vocals on hazard duty pay which pairs very well with peggy&#39;s forceful flow and blunt bars there&#39;s also the mysterious and beautiful thoughts prayer uh here peggy is as i was saying earlier interpolating britney spears and he&#39;s no stranger to covering or doing an artistic nod to 2000&#39;s era pop but in my opinion this track&#39;s probably the best example of that he&#39;s done britney&#39;s original flow and lyrics are given a strange new life within this spacious woozy beat meanwhile what kind of wrapping is this is a heavenly cut featuring these swirling wonderful harps and gorgeous vocal samples sounds like a fusion of triphop and r b from the future then peggy&#39;s bars on the track are pretty much cheeky commentary about the quality of a lot of hip hop lyricism today the novelty of his style how long he&#39;s been at it the whole track is euphoric funny and effortlessly charming are you happy sees things shifting on this lp into more of a grimy old-school memphis vibe but with some weird post-modern glitches laced into the beat from front to back the whole thing is pretty much proof of how entrancing and surreal peggy&#39;s songwriting and production can get when he wants it to be however the song rebound is very different in that it is totally out for blood not only is this one of the hardest jpeg mafia beats ever with its gigantic drums eerie tones and grand horns but there&#39;s also a great feature from dapif mafia that coincides with a slight bassy beat switch and merciless bars from peggy 2 why would i pray for your health baby i pray for myself then it would seem the final verse of the track addresses uh some personal beef that peggy seems really passionate about from here we move into the second half of the project which in my opinion is just as strong as the first the song og features some hilariously sassy bars from peggy some classic hip-hop rhythms and a sample of just ices the original gangster of hip-hop the whole track successfully pulls off having a foot in the old and the foot in the new it&#39;s like a post-industrial trippy hardcore hip-hop it almost reminds me in a way aesthetically of uh that wonderful beastie boys record i love so much that&#39;s a freaking underrated as [ __ ] hello nasty then the glossy tired nervous and broke has one of the strongest choruses on the entire lp really shows that peggy knows his way around a hook when he wants to pull one off but what&#39;s funny is that i&#39;m not even sure if the song is as catchy or as compelling as the somber uh raw piano outro featured on the track uh sung by peggy and obviously a guest who i guess is miraculously kimbra kimbra but yeah that portion of the song is just so goddamn cutting emotionally it&#39;s like your favorite saddest radiohead song then there&#39;s the inventive bmt which brings together this super compressed distorted lo-fi hip-hop beat some military march calls and some marimba as well it&#39;s an insane collection of vibes and it all pairs again perfectly with peggy&#39;s voice which cuts very well through all the chaos the ghost of ranking dread is easily one of the most epic and linear songs on the entire record i love tk mize&#39;s very alluring and somewhat eerie vocals on the front end which are touched up with auto-tune and harmonized in a way where they feel kind of strange and robotic eventually all this builds up to a very futuristic palette a wall of sound that wall that i referred to earlier with the synths and guitars layering up in a somewhat hellish and dystopian way peggy really nailing the sound design and the structure on this track wonderfully this is honestly like some left field sci-fi netflix series type [ __ ] then there&#39;s untitled which isn&#39;t uh as bold or as strong as showing instrumentally but i still think is a somewhat fitting closer because peggy does leave us with a parting flex and some words of wisdom so yeah there are tons of great tracks on this thing great verses great vocal performances great production great songwriting it&#39;s so flavorful it&#39;s so bold i do have a few critiques of the whole thing overall because i do think the flow of the record is a tad bit choppy there are some breezy instrumental bits that as i go back and i listen to the lp maybe aren&#39;t as striking or aren&#39;t as engaging as some of the core songs i also found um end credits to be maybe a bit too scant a bit too fleeting of a moment but i still see lp as an improvement on a lot of fronts peggy is getting better at writing biting lyrics employing song structure when he needs to the production here is easily more boundary pushing uh the track list is pretty stacked with weirdo hits on top of weirdo hits it&#39;s so layered and detailed as well every time i listen to it another bar or another like instrumental bit or nuance sticks out yeah with lp i think peggy continues to you know just flex his abilities as just being a jack of all trades a guy who&#39;s a rapper a singer a songwriter a producer just a little bit of everything and doing all of it incredibly well i&#39;m feeling a light too decent nine on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano jpeg mafia forever

title: By the Time I Get to Phoenix
transcript: hi everyone Anthony fantano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of this new injury reserve project by the time I get to Phoenix this is the latest project from Phoenix hip hop outfit injury reserve their second Studio LP to date following up their self-titled in 2019 which was officially their debut though it did come after years of fan favorite mixtapes and the drive it like it&#39;s stolen EP I&#39;ve been following injury reserves ride since the release of early singles that preceded their live from the dentist breakout mixtape and it&#39;s been exciting to see them progress artistically but also disheartening to see their fun and Forward Thinking approach to rap music fall on deaf ears within much of the industry that self-title definitely did make a dent forcing many outlets to really pay attention to them with some more accessible tracks and bigger features though personally I don&#39;t think it lived up to be their best workto date now under normal conditions any other group most likely would have built off the Rapport and momentum set by that record with a new release but the pandemic year a darker world and the untimely passing of key member Jordan Alexander grogs has put injury reserve in an unforeseen position where the you know future of the group is pretty much up in the air right now but in an interview I had with remaining members Nathaniel Richie and Parker Corey they said they finished much of the lp before all of this and because of its dark and Abstract Direction it still felt fitting to put out and that&#39;s certainly what the singles teased toward as well there was the heart-wrenching knees which brought these Stark hits of guitars and drums over which Richie brings this pained and ghostly vocal delivery that blurs the lines between the performance style of a rapper an R&amp;B artist and a rock frontman the track even blurs the boundaries of uh what is I guess a song as there are moments here where Richie&#39;s lyrics and vocals feel less like a performance and more like an internal monologue wrapped in off-kilter rhythms glitchy effects and disorienting vocal samples as a whole though the song feels like singing a very quiet song to yourself at a point where where you are at your lowest while also dealing with a pounding headache then there was also Superman that which was even more disorienting in comparison with its wild frantic glitchy rhythms that are still baffling to me at this point in one breath feel like I&#39;m listening to a more direct and pummeling version of something off of an ARCA record one of her more I guess uh deconstructed and glitch oriented projects while Richie&#39;s vocals in the midst of this chaos are giving off this ranting raving autotuned 808s and heartbreak Kanye level energy the ending of the track is a little abrupt but the ride up until that point is completely dizzying overwhelming too but in the midst of of all of this injury reserve still manages to convey some very potent emotions like the song knes this track brings I think some really serious feelings of helplessness or even impending doom so with teaser tracks with singles like these I went into this album wondering is every track going to be this like left field and by the time I get to Phoenix is almost more out there than I anticipated it would be to the point where I find some pockets of the record groundbreaking and a little difficult to Define so there&#39;s outside the intro track which is a pretty mysterious beginning to the record and feels like I&#39;m listening to a dystopian rap battle SLS spoken word piece the stage is set with some sampled bars from New York Battle Rapper dot then immediately after Richie comes in rapping against that with his vocals pitched down almost as if he is performing in response but not literally it&#39;s not like he&#39;s going at the guy or anything like that I I think this is sort of setting the stage on this track in order to illustrate these themes of division expressed throughout the song it&#39;s a really immense intro to the record and I think speaks to the direness of our current times and I think speaks to the emotional heaviness of this record overall as well as it very much feels like I&#39;m staring into a black hole that I&#39;m slowly getting sucked into SS San Francisco with z- Loopers is also a serious head scratcher the instrumental on this one sounds like I&#39;m listening to some depressive rockabilly or uh maybe even some Tom weights from like the bone machine ERA with its twangy and strange guitar leads and brooding bass meanwhile the vocals Richie and Z Loopers throw on top are bringing cross-sections of Psych and blues and experimental Rock then the following rap verses that pop in are the epitome of abstract hip-hop with Illusions to just how dark the world is right now but also with that train of thought being constantly interrupted with other musings and happenings and I guess you know just things trailing off a little bit mentally the song itself Trails off a little bit in the end but as I listen to it and also enjoy it I do kind of wonder what is even the most reasonable way to end this because as I dig deeper into this record not only does it feel like a lot of it is in reaction to the disarray of the world but also the disarray of the self the song footwork in a forest fire starts off well enough with the dreary Loi guitar and drum Loops grogg&#39;s Wild verse on the front end of the song is incredible feels like a more extreme take on the freakier directions Kanye was going in vocally on yeus though I do think the song begins to lose some steam in the second half especially with that uh guitar Loop and drum Loop staling out a little bit truth be told this is maybe the least Dynamic instrumental on the record thus far so as a result I think Richie&#39;s performance on the song doesn&#39;t come off as refreshing as it should though I do kind of like the way the song melts and disintegrates on the back end it does bring some cool soundplay to the table and I have no doubt with the title in mind here uh injury reserve was overtly referencing the highly publicized forest fires that have been raging across the planet and intensifying as a result of climate change the song Ground Zero philosophically in terms of its title I think is very much pulling from a similar type of energy maybe it&#39;s not directly in reference to 911 or anything like that but when we use terminology like Ground Zero we&#39;re often talking about a location where something catastropic happens instrumentally the track brings these heavy warped descending tones stuttering rhythms a very lowkey delivery from Richie as well he kind of mutters his way through these somewhat violent and very materialistic bars I do like the vibe and the sentiment of the song overall how it fits into the record but I do wish it had a stronger progression to it then smoke don&#39;t clear is another moment where oddly enough I&#39;m kind of reminded of Tom weights once again but like a totally different era like the real gone ERA with all these distorted looped hip-hop influence beats then there&#39;s also Richie&#39;s purposefully Gravely and very over-the-top delivery on it then with all the fuzzy textures and Primal rhythms in the instrumental 2o it&#39;s just another spot where injury reserve is just unabashedly throwing me for a loop then top picks for you once again again pulls deeply from that 808s and heartbreak era but then goes a bit more abstract with it with this strange wintry and vast soundscape then we have Richie on top of this delivering this blend of rap and spoken word with some haunting and ingenious Reflections on death and existential patterns likening the sequences that you might see in a life cycle to that of an Internet algorithm which honestly I think makes for one of the most apt moments conceptually on the entire project I think Wild Wild West also expands on this project themes of technology and apocalypse 2o with Richie on this instrumental ranting madly about 5G towers and bars like Willie Smith with the Inspector Gadget is more than just like a funny jux position as these things are brought up in reference to spying and intrusion this may also work as a meta commentary on the growing presence of conspiracies in popular and social media then post postpartum is another spot instrumentally that I get a lot out of it feels like an experiment m al post-industrial take on the Soulful sweet psychedelic sounds of outcast aesthetically I think it also sets the stage really well for the following track knes and conceptually I think this track is a hilarious way for uh injury reserve to kind of claim their influence with Richie saying his and their artistic impact is uh you know leading to them a birthing dudes really going into that with a lot of passion and detail and I think the extra level of hilarity with that on this track is everything injury reserve is pulling off on this record is just so far off from what like uh a trend seeking or a desperate for attention artist would want to copycat or even be able to copy cat honestly then we have the closing Track by storm which I think leaves the record off with a glimmer of hope in a way the instrumental here is rooted in these really fuzzy driving bits of guitar and bass in fact is a sample lifted from the closing track to one of my favorite Brian Eno records here come the warm Jets on top of that Richie is talking about uh you know that old adage when it rains it pours and it&#39;s really pouring and uh given the global events of the past couple of years and again injury reserve losing a key member I would say that is in fact the case but as Richie States on this track The Show Must Go On And even though things do look really dark there is kind of like a you know willingness to continue and a hopefulness to uh the vibe here that I I think is unignorable even if it&#39;s not said as as explicitly as it could be so overall uh I walked away from this record really blown away and impressed this thing is a bold inventive and I think genre bending and blurring project really one of the first records in hip-hop since the release of like deathgrips early stuff that uh to my ears feels like you know this is like transcending the the hip-hop genre a little bit but also kind of just expanding it as well I find it relatively refreshing that this record overall is a pretty compact listening experience but by that same token there are some ideas instrumentally and sonically I think could have been teased out developed a little bit further explored a bit deeper in terms of like length on a track or more variation within what has already been presented there are moments when Phoenix I think is a bit too brief but despite those very minor shortcomings This Record is the experimental out there abstract hip-hop release that I think everybody should be listening to this year if that is a direction that you happen to find yourself going into at any point because this is just great in my opinion it totally blows their self-titled project out of the water and simultaneously feels so familiar but also so different to feeling a strong eight to a light nine on this one artist: Floating Points, Pharoah Sanders & The London Symphony Orchestra
title: Promises
transcript: hi everyone here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of the new floating points and pharaoh sanders record promises featuring the london symphony orchestra this is a collaboration between not one not two but kind of three amazing names in the world of music one samuel t shepherd aka floating points a uk electronic music producer whose short but eclectic discography is known not just to cover idm and progressive electronic music but also classical and jazz as well two saxophonist pharaoh sanders one of the true living legends of jazz has played with numerous greats across his career and is mostly known for his contributions to spiritual jazz so through some amazing alignment of the stars these two have crossed over and then decided a pivotal tool to help their collaboration flourish would be the london symphony orchestra and of course it&#39;s been released on the record label that david byrne started in the late 80s to release brazilian and latin music that he was obsessed with at the time as well as his own solo stuff and yes the label has dropped a ton of great music in a variety of genres over the years i just thought this was something that you should know so yes on promises what we essentially have is a very unlikely cross-section of figures creating a meditative multi-movement new jazz piece with an orchestral twist and let me specify that one more time we have one piece on this record going through multiple movements i point that out because this piece moves through what is essentially the same cycle of cords for its 47-minute run time but breaks this progression up with different instrumental palettes and movements over this theme so for one movement the keys may be more prominent for another the sax for yet another the strings true to sanders spiritual jazz roots it&#39;s pretty entrancing in other words it&#39;s a vibe but it&#39;s also more than that often in my reviews i will cite instances on a song on a section of a song where there&#39;s a lot of movement a great progression but what can also be great is when a piece of music has an alluring stillness to it a sense of place artists who achieve this tend to hang more in the ambient and experimental realms but not always and there are points where promises does throw caution to the wind but for the most part this is a very stable composition whose magic is displayed through these immensely beautiful instrumental shifts that i think will woo nearly any music listener there&#39;s also a cleanliness a clarity a pristine quality to the sound of this project which i sort of expected given the london symphony orchestra tie-in but it doesn&#39;t take away from the heart and the soul of the peace in my opinion and for the most part complements the more electronic aesthetics of the piece too the whole thing kicks off with this beautiful first movement that works in two parts essentially an introduction to the foundational chords of the piece repeating them to the point where the listener may feel like they&#39;re being just brought into a lull a sense of serenity or familiarity and then pharaoh sanders begins running through an expressive passionate sac solo for the next five minutes i know this is just the first step of the record but between these glossy keys and sanders course but dynamic sax playing this is a sound i just want to be lost in even at this point there is a weightlessness and a vastness to promises that uh puts me in a state of just feeling like uh i&#39;m spinning through a a starry open space i don&#39;t know what is up and what is down the introduction of strings and electronics make the next couple of shorter movements in this piece melt into each other nicely the core musical theme of the piece remains strong and clear and constant meanwhile shepard and sanders and the orchestra are subtly diversifying the instrumental palettes movement four of the piece brings on some oddly intimate humming and vocalizations for a moment it&#39;s uh interesting how this changes up the vibe of everything so instantaneously because everything of it so far feels so isolated but there&#39;s kind of like a warmth to that moment that just makes it feel uh not so um lonely the fiery sax playing that comes later in this particular movement is a lot darker relies on deeper heavier tones this smoothly transitions into movement 5 which gets a little chaotic it&#39;s like everything we&#39;ve been hearing up until this point but the chaos of the previous movement has brought all of these elements up to a boiling point there&#39;s more blending and bleeding and volatility i feel like i&#39;m listening to the musical equivalent to a chemical reaction all of the elements here are turning into a steamy soup of sound on movement six much of the base instrumentation flushes out to really give a spotlight to the strings there are some heavy immense dense passages of music on this one that i love the bright orchestral arrangements really do make for a climactic moment movement 7 tones things down for some spacey ambient electronics that cycle into infinity then we get a radical but simple change on the eighth movement where pretty much everything is replaced with a very dirty organ but the isolation of the organ in this spot does allow for creative musical embellishments on the chords we&#39;ve been hearing so far in many ways the ninth and final movement of the piece is even more low-key you can tell shepard and sanders are really trying to ease us out of this experience the orchestrations come back it&#39;s very delicate it&#39;s quite cinematic and in a nutshell that is the piece that is promises and it&#39;s quite lovely it&#39;s really one of the best musical experiences i&#39;ve had this year there are some movements i think could have used a bit more variation but as is the mix the instrumentation here is gorgeous is immaculate the whole experience again is truly meditative and entrancing and creatively speaking this project is a cool cross-section of jazz electronic music and classical without any one of those elements being to the detriment of the other feeling a light to decent nine on this one tran position have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano music forever

title: Visions of Bodies Being Burned
transcript: hi everyone spookthenebu tano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of the new clipping album visions of bodies being burned titled after a bar from the ghetto boys song mind playing tricks on me which is sampled in the second track of this album visions of bodies being burned is essentially the sister record to clippings last full-length lp one year ago it was dropped there existed in addiction to blood which thematically was a hard turn into horror core territory while still maintaining their harsh and creative approach to sound now this horror core switch-up also manifested in the embrace of some horror movie soundtrack aesthetics there were some instrumentals on this thing that had some serious john carpenter vibes but the trio also took their sound play to the next level 2 on some tracks whether that&#39;s on run for your life where there&#39;s all sorts of sound effects indicating that rapper david diggs is spitting his bars outside including a moment where a car is driving by a beat is playing out the window and that beat just happens to sync up with the rhythm of his rhymes then there was also piano burning which was a take on anil lockwood&#39;s conceptual piano burning performance pieces and yeah it&#39;s literally audio of a piano burning for 18 minutes so jonathan snipes and william hudson totally killed it on the sonic end of things here as they usually do but let&#39;s not also forget here david flexing his talents not just as a rapper but as a narrator on this one because he&#39;s telling legitimately hair-raising stories track after track here so that brings us to visions of bodies which for all intents and purposes is pretty much another helping of all of that which i can&#39;t stress enough is a good thing it&#39;s actually really impressive the one two punch that clipping has assembled here staying true to their style and their sound while embarking on a new concept which they have kept fresh for two different records a year apart both of which explore said concept in different ways on different tracks while pushing sonic boundaries from end to end we have 16 cuts on this thing which include a handful of interludes to space things out and of course what&#39;s a clipping album without an intro so loud and distorted that that sound hits your ears with the crackle of a wildfire the intro starts with these deep thunderous resonant thumps basically the sound of something frightening approaching the pounding and the pounding becomes louder and clearer eventually becoming the rhythmic backing for david&#39;s rapping which sounds like it&#39;s coming out of a very small phone speaker like he&#39;s some kind of killer telling you the last thing you&#39;re gonna hear before you die there are some really strange and interesting rhythmic switch-ups in davie&#39;s rhymes and eventually as he starts to gain up a very fast amount of momentum he hits you with that it&#39;s clipping following this is the infectious and groovy say the name that ghetto boy&#39;s loop is absolutely an ear worm the baseline is sick too i also love how the instrumental generally is so dark it&#39;s so heavy and yet it&#39;s not super busy either it&#39;s simple but effective david&#39;s cold-blooded flows dance on top of these grooves as they develop into something that feels like i don&#39;t know nine-inch nails closer but uh with a smooth clubby flare however the sound of the song in its beginning stages is a stark contrast from all of the grand twangy and metallic instrumentation building up in the final leg that sounds like an industrial take on persian music not entirely sure where that&#39;s coming from but it is an amazing display of sound and quite a cool transition lyrically david borrows a lot of themes from classic slasher flicks portraying a bunch of young sexy protagonists getting ready to party but they&#39;re actually just going to be butchered to death while also tying that into the horror folklore of the candy man you say his name five times which has parallels with bloody mary pretty classic trope at this point that is incorporated very creatively we also have 96 nev campbell who is obviously known for playing a major role in the scream movie franchise and the song ends up being another groovy murderous banger that goes into somewhat familiar territory for them it&#39;s not a conceptual take on a slasher flick per se though i do think that sound effect of the bang bang bang worked into the beat is pretty genius rather you can add this song to the steady stream of clipping tracks that feature strong deadly female characters the most obvious of which is body and blood in the first leg of the song david builds up this story of a mean merciless queen pretty much setting up guest rappers cam in china for success as they go to town on the beat with one slick and threatening bar after another they also sound completely unfazed by the potential of a deadly killer who would most likely just become their prey anyway then with the following something underneath things become a lot more narrative and a lot less accessible bustling stuttering disorienting noise becomes the soundtrack to some pretty unnerving bars about a flood of i think possessed cannibals rising up very violently out of the earth and consuming basically anything that moves make them dead seize the trio pushing things into even more abrasive territory as david spits screeds over a wall of harsh distortion ear piercing tones if you&#39;re not into noise and power electronics um you might be kind of departing here but if you are it&#39;s some legitimately decimating sound design regardless though i do love the track&#39;s cultish vocal harmonies and the way the compression on those kick drums really shake the distortion in the drones and the instrumental lyrically david seems to be going into the details of a ritualistic murder i&#39;m sure the narrative&#39;s open to interpretation to some degree but it&#39;s pretty clear that an obsession with tradition and faith leads a group of people to forming a death cult based on religious rule then there&#39;s also the very funny and freaky she bad which when i think of that phrase what comes to mind is usually someone sexy with unshakable confidence style and attitude but against hair-raising sound effects deep bass and twittering electronics the she that is so bad that david is describing is a murderous ghost that lives in the woods with dust skin and snake eyes and a forked tongue i&#39;m not even going to tell you what happens to the unassuming group of partiers that saunter into the forest she haunts then pain every day is an absolutely mind-blowing spot on the record for the way it seamlessly brings together intricate idm rhythms horrifying sound effects grand string sections and a totally unique flow in 7 8 time and all of it progresses so naturally it works so well check the lock is another smooth operator with a killer baseline about a protagonist who is incredibly paranoid he&#39;s checking his locks he&#39;s checking under the hood of his car he&#39;s checking his rear view mirror he&#39;s driving through yellow lights he&#39;s suspicious there&#39;s something different now about the room that he&#39;s in clearly a guy who&#39;s afraid of being offed by a rival or an enemy and the way david lyrically dives into that paranoia it&#39;s pretty potent the following looking like meat though in my opinion is one of the weaker moments here not for nothing but i think the beat on this one is a little overbearing yeah i know it&#39;s not the only loud production on this record but between the massively distorted bass the massively distorted beats and david&#39;s massively distorted vocals there&#39;s not a lot of dynamics to it not a lot of sonic diversity in a way it feels almost like a throwback to a lot of the very abrasive material from their first mixtape but nowhere near as catchy then the atmospheric eerie and horror-inspired choruses that glide in very smoothly feel almost tacked on because they don&#39;t complement the distortion all that well bringing punk wrap duo horror on for a feature definitely adds to the edgy and aggressive tone of the track but not its dynamics in terms of ideas it just feels like one of the thinner songs here but there&#39;s not really a sticky beat or hook to make up for that visions of bodies does have a pretty strong ending though eaton alive features some uniquely layered wrapping that is super simple but still spine tingling the instrumental mainly consists of these scattered percussive sounds and loud metallic tones lyrically david is bringing together hip hop and horror swamp aesthetics for bar after bar big rims tall grass missing teeth but the molars are gold a wish a would step up in this swamp cause i guess after that point these scary swamp people are are gonna kill you the noisy instrumental freakout at the end is a really cool and unexpected change of pace certainly plays into the trio&#39;s tradition of celebrating different forms of avant-garde and noise-based music too then we have the very morbid body for the pile which a lot of you who are clipping fans may be familiar with at this point the release of the song goes back to 2016 so nothing entirely new here but still it&#39;s awesome just how much the instrumental and themes of the song play into the already established sounds and ideas of this record it&#39;s just pretty much slipping on like a glove plus given all the anti-police brutality protests as of late the ideas of this track are more relevant now than ever then to top things off with in lacing we have another smooth head nodding banger with massive bass love the haunting and hypnotic pitched vocal samples in the instrumental on this one also david sung hook too some of the best and most surrealist bars on this and there existed turn up here while the way the blinds can play that tattoo stripes across the face that wait how are you looking at your face when your face is on your face this is something you should face you should the song slap though the whole thing is like having an acid trip during an apocalyptic trap song and as far as the horror element of this track goes it&#39;s certainly moving into more psychological territory then to finish things off like they usually do clipping offers their own take on a piece of process music or a performance art piece this time it&#39;s yoko ono&#39;s secret piece which is a pretty interesting and perfect way to end this project because not only does it allow them to bring their collaborators back in a really subtle way to just add to the record one more time but the sounds of birds chirping and dawn as it were rising allows these two horror themed albums to finish off i guess on a somewhat positive note things are brighter next day is here the creepy things have gone away and overall wow just wow one amazing track after another i think uh catchier and harder hitting a little bit more than there existed though both records are fantastic and i think add to each other in a myriad of different ways as an overall experience and art piece clipping just continues to prove themselves as one of the most groundbreaking boundary-pushing and creative acts out there in hip-hop in modern music in general and just can&#39;t wait to hear what they do next they absolutely killed it on this one feeling a decent two strong nine here tran position have you title: Last Year Was Weird, Vol. 2
transcript: anthony b tano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it&#39;s time for a review of the new ep from tk maiza last year was weird volume 2. this is a new ep of tracks from australian rappers singer and songwriter tk miza who for years has been making a massive amount of sound down under becoming one of the most versatile and creative voices to rise up out of strya&#39;s robust music scene her talents have been recognized internationally to a slight degree thus far i mean how many australian artists can boast a killer mic feature on their dblp but her 2016 self-titled record does feel like a lifetime ago in terms of evolution overall it is a very fun pop rap record with an experimental edge a lot of dance beats and huge m.i.a vibes she has since expanded into trap neo-soul and a larger variety of dance grooves with this last year was weird series that began in 2018 and now we are getting the second installment of that and it is easily one of the best collections of songs i have heard in 2020. this ep is so consistently good and stylistically diverse that it&#39;s hard to believe the songs here are all attributed to one artist we have the opening track my flowers which is a delicate funky and enveloping piece of neo soul with an immaculate hook attached to it these are my flowers these are my flowers i just need to be cradled in this quest love type beat the warm keys and tk&#39;s super cute melodic silky flows it&#39;s enchanting then we have a total mood switch on the equally good 24k where tk suddenly breaks into a quality piece of hip house feels kind of like something kaytranada or goldlink would do but tk is kind of killing them on on their sound kind of killing them a little bit with love the vocals in comparison with the opener are a lot bolder the flows are fun and she drops some cheeky bars about money fashion and of course tetris which believe it or not is not the only tetris bar on the ep then we get shook which is a blaring and funky piece of pop wrap that feels like a combination of missy elliot and pharrell we have this booming lunch table beat on the song some bold synth hits some interesting transitions along the way too then beyond that it&#39;s all about tk with these super carefree infectious bars that remind me of stuff the cool kids used to do back in the day great hook too next the song awake shouldn&#39;t be too new to anyone in my audience not only because there is a jpeg mafia feature on it but i also named this track as one of my favorite tracks of 2019. this thing is a dark grimy trap banger with a slightly industrial beat i also love the thematic bars about staying awake at all hours of the night being an insomniac essentially feeling wired in the information age then tk keeps things kind of moody and aggressive on the following grasshopper which in my opinion between the grooves and the flows does have a very subtle a very slight grime edge to it i love that she has dipped into that sound even if just a little bit on this one plus i think the track list being as short as it is could have used another banger so good thing this song got worked into the mix i love the way tk&#39;s flow in the second verse gets super melodic really switching it up to the point where it&#39;s like she plays her own feature on the song which is a funny sensation she creates also on the track pb jam another neo soul cut with lots of bass punchy drums some light subtle touches of psychedelic effects here and there on a few elements there&#39;s also kind of a breathy chill kaliyuchi&#39;s vibe to the song as well but it&#39;s more of a similarity than a rip-off then again just before the midpoint of the song tk comes through with this super bold sassy verse that&#39;s like wow you&#39;re doing everything it&#39;s like you sound so radically different in this rap verse than you do with all the vocals everywhere else you&#39;re just you&#39;re just being your own feature you&#39;re you&#39;re three different voices you&#39;re five different styles you&#39;re everywhere it&#39;s fantastic of course i have to give a nod to these songs which is a bubbly pop cut with a huge bossa nova flavor coming through on the guitars funny ad-libs playful lead vocals and a gorgeous pre-chorus overall just a great tune with lots of personality and lyrics about pettiness and cutting people out of your life who i guess are just toxic then laughing at the way their toxicity makes them miserable and unhappy then with the closing track don&#39;t call me again with kari foe this one is a pretty grand closer in terms of emotional potency there is a lot of heartache here stylistically the track sounds like a seamless throwback of 90s pop and more neo-soul but with a crisp contemporary delivery that keeps it from feeling like an exercise in nostalgia tk&#39;s vocal harmonies on the track are fantastic and foe&#39;s rap verse on the song has this deep vocal tone to it so confident so commanding it&#39;s just the thing the song needed yeah there is not a single dud on this ep there really is not i do think tk does still have little ways to go in terms of redefining her influences flipping them in a way that is a bit more distinct and also refining things down until she hits upon a sound that is truly uniquely her but still that does not take away from the fact that we have nothing but good songs good production good performances sticky lyrics and interesting variety of styles as well and finally from front to back hit after hit after hit after hit feeling a light too decent nine on this ep tran position have you given this ep a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i title: Miles
transcript: uh hi everyone big thingy burp tano here the internet&#39;s busiest music nerd and it is time for a review of the new blue and exile album miles this is the latest collection of songs from two west coast underground legends rapper blue producer exile about 13 years ago these two offered one of the best hip-hop albums to come out of california in the 2000s below the heavens a witty thoughtful and uplifting set of tracks that put these two on the map sadly though the music industry utterly failed to elevate their respective talents in the coming years especially blue whose big major label debut new york was completely botched in terms of roll out but as soon as he was released from his obligations to warner brothers records his creativity began to flow again as did exiles they eventually linked up once more with blue writing to a ton of beats that exile had passed him which would eventually become their 2011 record give me my flowers while i can still smell them which was a good release but not nearly as focused or as high impact as below the heavens was more of a surreal vibey and abstract experience so that was it 2011 that was the last time these two dropped a record together now of course blue and exile have respectively been involved in respectable projects since then blue&#39;s record with oh no a long red hot los angeles summer night i think is one of his best in general but for many fans of blue and exiles music nothing has hit quite like their stuff together which leads us to miles where these two are really making up for lost time with 20 tracks and 95 minutes of material there are actually multiple tracks on this thing that reach 5 minutes 6 minutes the song roots of blue breezes past 9 minutes without an issue and it&#39;s just blue wrapping there are quite a few tracks here where blue is bringing back that fabled third verse and sometimes even the fourth verse so blue and exile aren&#39;t just giving a lot on this record they&#39;re asking a lot too because this is a lot of material but miraculously the songs on miles aren&#39;t really all that hard to appreciate somehow this album has managed the laser-focused conceptuality of below the heavens but reaching a few layers deeper while also pulling off the pillowy textured jazz laced ecstasy of give me my flowers but again like a bit elevated in terms of quality and detail so yes the sound of this record for blue and exile it is familiar this is familiar territory but simultaneously the both of them sound wise beyond their years at this point blue seems to have so much more personal experience to pull from in his bars as he dives into fatherhood spirituality america hip-hop jazz you could make a whole ep of the songs on this album where he&#39;s just going at the blue angle on this record blue as i can be all the blues you ain&#39;t never blue just to name a couple and it&#39;s interesting that blue can approach a topic on a song and then return to it later on the album with a different reference point or a different angle and still have it sound refreshing whether it be the song miles davis where blue is going on about mastering his artistic craft or retelling the personal story and history of miles davis on the song all the blues and then with spread sunshine with the constant mentioning of traveling miles and miles to this place and that place in this place it&#39;s a really cool characteristic to the album that makes the entire hour and a half of it feel really cohesive since most of the tracks seem to be narratively linked together like a labyrinth of secret caves now before i get into the specifics of some of the tracks here keep in mind the vast majority of the large amount of material on this record is impeccable i didn&#39;t really get the sense that any of what i heard here was throw away or filler just to kill time and the magic behind these songs is pretty simple beats and rhymes good beats and rhymes some of the best beats and rhymes blue and exile have been responsible for the production highlights on this thing are many really too many to name but i do love the dramatic and unlikely groove and surreal vocal samples and angelic strings on the opener blue red yellow green then we get the booming kicks and what sounds like barbershop style vocal harmonies on when the gods meet i&#39;m very unsure about the origin of this vocal sample or really the style that it&#39;s supposed to be embodying but i do love what it&#39;s doing for the track aesthetically and i think exile chops it up beautifully the thick rush of keys that hit the high contrast chorus on the song are absolutely perfect too there&#39;s also some rich pianos a gently funky beat warm bass on the song the feeling the whole thing sounds like a deep orangey sunrise hitting some city streets in the early am the whole vibe of the instrumental is cinematic it&#39;s gorgeous it&#39;s moving i get a similar vibe from the beat on the american dream but a bit peppier troubled water the way the tragic vocal harmonies hit against the very heavy classic boombap groove on this track it sounds like a kanye throwback the production on roots of blue takes an oddly primal turn with what sounds like some hand percussion with a wooden timbre a dark bluesy acoustic guitar lick hefty hip-hop drums some indigenous vocal samples it is such a fantastically hypnotic loop and vibe that again goes for nine minutes this is the longest track on the entire lp and yet over the course of this song it never really gets stale with dear lord the vintage and anthemic horns along with the gospel style vocal harmonies with the gemetta rose hook is enough to bring tears to my eyes this track instrumentally and lyrically too is like a flawless beam of hope and aspiration and positivity that is just so desperately lacking in everything right now beyond that there are the many many and i mean many songs that function off of really colorful beautiful and fantastic jazz samples which would add five or ten more minutes onto the review to go over every single one but there is a lot of high quality production on this record and blue does some great things with it whether it be the color based wordplay on the intro to the record which i think is really smart thoughtful and inspiring or the song the feeling where blue goes over essentially how the music industry kind of chewed him up and spit him out but for him of course to live to see another day tell the tale and creatively come out ahead music is my everything sees blue rapping about his earliest introductions to popular music and the way his life intersected with it beyond that including his mom marrying a preacher who said that secular music was off limits essentially these are just a few of many tales of personal progression on this album including brightest stars which not only has a great guest feature from freestyle fellowships ac alone but if you listen close here you&#39;ll also hear blue rapping about starting out rapping and wanting to essentially hit listeners with really materialistic and conceited bars but then growing beyond that because he felt like he wasn&#39;t being true to himself blue as i can be then stands out for its relentless flows and super intricate rhyme patterns blue&#39;s performance here is just incredible troubled water as well scratches a similarly flashy itch then with miles away we see blue getting nostalgic sentimental rapping about being away traveling others being away talking about people he knows caught up in the prison system or his cousins being drafted but then simultaneously the song is also about traveling miles moving forward progressing changing just one more super thoughtful moment on the record essentially then to go back to the track roots of blue i am consistently blown away at just how all encompassing this song is with blue rapping about the early civilizations african tribes abrahamic religions american slavery the roots of various american music genres for verse after verse after verse blue is just on another level of conceptuality when it comes to hip-hop right now you could say a lot of these themes get extended into the song african dream but with more of an afrocentric angle then blue showcases more entrepreneurial aspirations on the song the american dream which is not just a series of bars about his own personal hopes and dreams but it&#39;s simultaneously a commentary on the almighty dollar being america&#39;s religion essentially lyrically dear lord is such a powerful message of unity and peace and empathy and caring just really destroying and breaking down everything that separates mankind from this possibility be it borders or war violence bigotry hatred organized religion we then get hit with one of the weirder tracks in the tracklist in my opinion to the fall but not forgotten there are some cultural figures that he name drops that you know might not be the best i mean like fidel castro or dr sebby whose scientific methods weren&#39;t exactly like you know proven so truth be told there are some questionable bars on this record here and there but the lowest points on the album i found to be just underwhelming whether that be on the kind of bland true and livin whose verses i found to be kind of feel good but somewhat vague in their intentions then the song you ain&#39;t never blue features some rapping from exile who yes also does rap although he&#39;s not known to do it particularly well and that is very much apparent in this track here where he is lyrically going up against blue the color the sky water in my eyes line is kind of strange that other flubbed bar where he says put the sorrows in the verse and then it&#39;s like like there&#39;s there&#39;s something that feels lost in translation at this point and then the the get dap part of the line if you listen to it you&#39;ll know what i&#39;m saying there&#39;s definitely something like missing from this part or there was a stumble or whatever big blue soul you ain&#39;t even have a little put your hand out i&#39;ll give you my favorite color of skittle why why outside of those moments though this record is great i love this record i think it&#39;s a fantastic record one of the best hip-hop projects in either artist&#39;s discography potentially the best hip-hop project of this year and i think it&#39;s going to be a while before we hear a jazz rap album that steps to this one in terms of just how massive creative and well-crafted it is feeling a light nine on this one transition have you given this album a listen did you love it did you hate it what would you rate it you&#39;re the best you&#39;re the best what should i review next hit the like if you like please subscribe and please don&#39;t cry hit the bell as well over here next to my head is another video that you can check out hit that up or the link to subscribe to the channel anthony fantano music forever
